story:
Coral reefs are the rainforests of the ocean, and many of the world's fish species rely on them as breeding grounds, nurseries, and shelter.

This winter, record ocean warming associated with a major El Niño event is driving widespread coral bleaching, but so far those effects have gone largely undocumented. We need your help to gather data and samples that will help us understand how coral reefs will evolve under continued climate change.

Ocean temperatures have warmed by as much as 8F in the central tropical Pacific Ocean, making this area ground zero for coral bleaching and mortality that is going on right now. In fact, when we visited our research site in November, we saw that up to 90% of the corals were already bleached, some coral species were entirely wiped out. 

An urgent mission to the middle of the Pacific

My name is Dr. Kim Cobb, and I'm a climate scientist at Georgia Tech. In March, my collaborator Dr. Julia Baum and I will lead an ambitious field expedition back to Christmas Island, joined by some of the world's experts on coral ecology and climate change. We will make detailed surveys of the island's reefs via SCUBA, collect small samples of tissues from any surviving corals for genetic analysis, and install a number of environmental sensors on the reef to monitor ocean temperature, salinity, and pH.

Your donations will help fund:
flights to Christmas Island ($2,000 each)
food and lodging for the team ($1,000 per person per week)
boat rental for SCUBA dive operations ($400 per day)

Get involved in our historic expedition!

The easiest way to contribute is to help us get the word out.

And, for the first time ever, we are offering two donors the chance to join us on the expedition for one week! Do science and share in the thrill of the expedition's discoveries. Have the adventure of your lifetime in a place very few people will ever visit, but that we have fallen in love with. Interested in learning more? E-mail elnino2016@gatech.edu to arrange a chat with Prof. Kim Cobb. More details here. 

The Dream Team

Aside from myself and Julia Baum, we have a number of leading scientists who are lending their considerable expertise to the project, including:

Dr. Ruth Gates (Hawaii Inst. of Marine Biology; coral ecologist and coral genomicist)
Dr. Samantha Stevenson (Univ. of Hawaii; climate and ocean modeling)
Dr. Jessica Carilli (UMass-Boston; coral biogeochemistry)
Dr. Mark Hay (Georgia Tech; coral reef ecologist)

Read more about our science here:
Going "All In" for Science
What Influences coral survival through an extreme bleaching event?

The Big Picture - Corals and climate change

With ocean temperatures reaching new heights decade after decade, we expect that future natural temperature extremes will push reefs into unchartered territory. Of course, evidence that Prof. Cobb has amassed from fossil corals on Christmas Island suggests that climate change may already be fueling an increase in El Niño intensities (see her findings here). It seems likely that the world's reefs will experience acute thermal stress much more often under continued climate change. If so, then this El Niño provides us with a crystal ball of sorts into the future - one that we have the chance to study right now.

We have an extremely unique opportunity this spring - to document what an unprecedented temperature extreme does to an otherwise healthy reef. Which of the corals survived? And why? And how can we harness these lessons to foster greater resilience in future coral reefs?

These are just some of the big questions we'll be attempting to answer with the data and samples that we'll collect during this expedition. 

We have the right team, at the right place, at exactly the right time.

All we need is people like you to make it happen.
story_txt:
Coral reefs are the rainforests of the ocean, and many of the world's fish species rely on them as breeding grounds, nurseries, and shelter.
This winter, record ocean warming associated with a major El Niño event is driving widespread coral bleaching, but so far those effects have gone largely undocumented. We need your help to gather data and samples that will help us understand how coral reefs will evolve under continued climate change.
Ocean temperatures have warmed by as much as 8F in the central tropical Pacific Ocean, making this area ground zero for coral bleaching and mortality that is going on right now. In fact, when we visited our research site in November, we saw that up to 90% of the corals were already bleached, some coral species were entirely wiped out.    An urgent mission to the middle of the Pacific My name is Dr. Kim Cobb, and I'm a climate scientist at Georgia Tech. In March, my collaborator Dr. Julia Baum and I will lead an ambitious field expedition back to Christmas Island, joined by some of the world's experts on coral ecology and climate change. We will make detailed surveys of the island's reefs via SCUBA, collect small samples of tissues from any surviving corals for genetic analysis, and install a number of environmental sensors on the reef to monitor ocean temperature, salinity, and pH.
Your donations will help fund:flights to Christmas Island ($2,000 each)food and lodging for the team ($1,000 per person per week)boat rental for SCUBA dive operations ($400 per day)

Get involved in our historic expedition!
The easiest way to contribute is to help us get the word out.

And, for the first time ever, we are offering two donors the chance to join us on the expedition for one week! Do science and share in the thrill of the expedition's discoveries. Have the adventure of your lifetime in a place very few people will ever visit, but that we have fallen in love with. Interested in learning more? E-mail elnino2016@gatech.edu to arrange a chat with Prof. Kim Cobb. More details here. 
The Dream Team
Aside from myself and Julia Baum, we have a number of leading scientists who are lending their considerable expertise to the project, including:
Dr. Ruth Gates (Hawaii Inst. of Marine Biology; coral ecologist and coral genomicist)Dr. Samantha Stevenson (Univ. of Hawaii; climate and ocean modeling)Dr. Jessica Carilli (UMass-Boston; coral biogeochemistry)Dr. Mark Hay (Georgia Tech; coral reef ecologist)

story:
My name is Mia deLancellotti and I’m a sophomore at Lake Oswego High School.  I’m writing to ask for your support in a community service project that I plan to complete this summer. Rather than taking a vacation, I’ve decided to devote a few weeks of my time to volunteer for a wildlife conservation program. I went out and found a program in Thailand where I’ll have the chance to make a positive difference in the lives of others, and at the same time learn more about and care for injured elephants.

The organization I’m traveling with is called Walking Tree, and their mission is to inspire people to become global citizens by taking an active interest in the world around them. I’ll be traveling around Thailand with a group of students my age, and living with a host family in a small village where we’ll complete a community service project for half the time and also living at a research camp where I’ll be assisting researchers and experiencing a completely different culture. I chose this program because I want to help people have access to the same resources and services that we take for granted here in Lake Oswego, OR.

I’m really excited to be part of the Walking Tree team; there are less than 500 students that participate in these programs every year, and I’ve already been accepted to the program of my choice in Thailand. In order to go on the 21 day trip, I have to raise $5,000 to cover the cost of my tuition, airfare, and vaccinations. I am writing to ask if you would be willing to invest in me and the development of a community in need. All donations will be accepted. $100, $50, $25 or even just $10 is incredibly generous and I appreciate any amount donated.

story:
The Vehicle for Change: A Safe Home for an Activist Poet

I'm an internationally known activist poet with a long track record and a great project you can read about below, but in order to do it, I need a safe roof over my head.


Breaking news!  A valentine of a donor has offered to match the next $5000 I raise.  Every dollar you donate now is worth two.  (February 14, 2016)

My family home must go on the market this spring.  I have severe environmental illness, and have been living there until I could complete construction on the non-toxic, solar powered tiny home I've been designing for five years.  I must complete construction and move in by early April.

I am made very ill by conventional construction materials, common household chemicals, and mobile home components such as vinyl or propane stoves.  Although my family home is not ideal for my health, it has worked as a temporary solution.  But soon I won't have that option. Environmentally safe housing is extremely hard to find.  The last time I had to look, I spent several months sleeping in people's porches and offices.  But it's winter and I'm in New England.

For five years I've researched materials and components that work for my body, consulting a wide array of experts.  I raised over $150,000, and the structure has been built and insulated, wiring put in, th subfloor laid, and the metal ceiling and walls installed.  My construction team is working on finishing my house now.  They have generously allowed me to defer payment, but in order to finish up and move in, I will need to pay them, and purchase final materials. 

Reaching my campaign goals will allow me to do my work as an activist artist, and contribute to building a stronger and more inclusive environmental justice movement, but I also urgently need your support to get a safe roof over my head, and keep me independent, healthy, and secure.   


Letters from Earth

Letters from Earth is a poetic journalism project, part travelogue, part documentary, an exploration of the impacts of environmental injustice on our land and our bodies.

Starting in early 2016, I'll be traveling around the country in my tiny house on wheels, specially designed to be non-toxic, accessible and semi-sustainable, visiting the individuals, front line communities, and wild habitats most affected by our extract-and-consume economy, and writing and recording my most powerful poetic prose to tell their stories and my own. 

I want to inspire people to understand and act on both the urgency and the potential of this moment.    

Environmental injustice falls most heavily on people who are already facing multiple kinds of injustice in their lives, so Letters from Earth will center their lives, their bodies, their stories, and their leadership. 

My audio blogs will be broadcast nationally on Flashpoints, on listener sponsored Pacifica radio.   Text versions will also be posted on my website, and I will post calls to action for each edition of Letters from Earth, as well as links to further information.


Who I am

My name is Aurora Levins Morales.  I'm an internationally known, disabled and chronically ill Puerto Rican Jewish feminist writer, and I've been an activist artist all my life.  People tell me that my poetry and essays have given them courage and strength, hope and a sense of possibility.  People who heard me speak 25 years ago still write to me to tell me how their lives were changed. 

I am a survivor of both ecological and sexual violence. As a child, I was exposed to dangerous pesticides and pollutants, and to the international trade in child pornography.  My body has suffered from these assaults, and I live with disability, chronic pain, exhaustion, and severe chemical sensitivity as a result. My body is full of stories that also express the trouble of the world. 

I have been writing since I was a child.  I've read and spoken and hundreds of colleges and universities, my work appears in dozens of anthologies in more than seven languages, and I'm the author of Medicine Stories, Remedios: Stories of Earth and Iron from the History of Puertorriqueñas, Kindling: Writings On the Body, and co-author, with my mother Rosario Morales, of Getting Home Alive and Cosecha and Other Stories.  I have collaborated with the Bay Area based disabled artists performance project Sins Invalid since 2008. 

I feel called to respond to our ecological crisis by doing what I do best: bringing the tools of activist art to the task of changing the world.  To tell stories that bridge the gap between body and landscape, the personal and the global and inspire people to take action on behalf of the people they love and the planet that is our home.

I would love to have you with me on this journey.


Why poetry?  Why radio?

By itself, information doesn’t often change people’s minds.  We’re too well defended against it.  It’s like a nutrient our bodies can’t absorb.  Poetry can be a kind of co-factor that carries information into the heart and lets us feel our connection to it.  The imagery, emotion, metaphor and cadences of poetic prose are my most trusted tools with which to educate, agitate, move, and inspire the people around me. 

I love radio. I love its intimacy and its range.  I love how it makes us listen.  I grew up hearing broadcasts from around the world on shortwave radio, and co-produced a feminist radio show in my teens.  In the days after 9/11 I wrote a long poem that was broadcast on Flashpoints.  Response was overwhelming, and I began working as a Poet On Assignment, writing weekly poetic commentaries on the news.  My poet-journalist pieces continue to be broadcast, and always get a great response.

So now I've decided to use the combined power of poetry and radio to take on this crisis of our biosphere and its human societies.

 

Why a tiny house on wheels? 

I was born on a coffee farm in Puerto Rico in the mid-1950s, and was exposed to  dangerous pesticides as a very young child.   My body is genetically challenged at getting rid of toxins, so I became sick.  I had seizures and migraines, and multiple head injuries from falls, and over time my body started reacting to all kinds of common substances, including construction materials, petroleum products, household cleaning supplies, and personal care products. 

I could no longer ride buses, stay at hotels, or go to other people's homes, and I felt sick all the time.  I had become environmentally ill.  I spent a lot of time and money modifying my apartment to be a safe haven, and then, when my neighbors began spraying pesticides and venting laundry near my door, I became homeless and had to start over.  I realized then that the only way for me to have and keep a chemically safe home was to put it on wheels, so I had the freedom to leave when my location became toxic.

I began consulting experts in tiny houses, non-toxic materials, renewable energy, EMF fields, universal design and accessible technology, and have spent the last five years designing and starting to build a prototype non-toxic mobile house.  It's a model of chemically accessibility, and an expression of a big vision in which access and sustainability are one.  I call it the Vehicle for Change.

The frame, subfloor and walls are all aluminum to avoid plywood adhesives and mold.  It's superinsulated, has hardwood and ceramic tile floors and counters, is heated with a super-efficient, smokeless Kimberly wood stove, has water and air filters, a composting toilet, a solar cooker, natural fiber furnishings, and a solar powered electrical system.  

The Vehicle is part of the story I am telling:  How the contamination of our environment is a disability issue, a housing issue, and a public health issue.  How we need to find ways to survive and adapt while we work for deeper change. And that begins with our bodies and our homes.

 

Fundraising Phases One, Two and Three

In order to do the work I am setting out to do, I must finish building and furnishing my Vehicle, install my solar array and battery bank to allow me to live and work anywhere, set up my studio so I can write, record and access the internet, and buy a truck to pull the Vehicle.

Phase One

During the first phase of this project I raised $125,000 through individual donors, crowdfunding and interest free loans.  I was able to buy and insulate my custom trailer shell, pay for electrical and plumbing work, the interior walls, ceiling and floor, buy the Kimberly stove, PurEffect advanced water filtration system, custom storage units, and a ton of building materials.

Phase Two

This campaign will pay the balance I owe to my wonderful building crew, Community Builders Cooperative, my architect, electrician and plumber. 

Phase Three

The last stage includes my solar power system, a 3/4 ton "clean diesel" truck, the innovative Automatic Safety Hitch, and RV driver training.

Any funds over the $40,000 goal of this campaign will go to Phase Three.

We're actively seeking in-kind donations to lower the amount of cash I must raise, and interest free loans to give me more time to raise it. 
 

The Perks!

Honestly, I believe the biggest perk of this campaign for you and for me, is that you'll become part of my team, and we'll be doing this work together.  I'll  take you with me to the mountains where I was born in western Puerto Rico, and the birthplace of the Dupont Corporation, by the polluted Delaware River; to Louisiana's Gulf coast and notorious Cancer Alley, to the shale fields of North Dakota and the shorelines of the endangered Great Lakes, and into all the homes and meeting halls, forests and deserts I hope to visit.  When I am able to reach, inspire or connect people, you'll be a part of that.

But I have swag, too.
There are copies of my books, original digital art prints, special pencils, and a CD of my poetry, and other special perks along the way.

I'm also launching two special clubs, with early bird discounts.  

Book Club members will get my in depth recommendations of 3 books per season (12  a year) and access to a closed discussion forum where you can join me to talk about them.

Audio Club members will get recordings from my journey--back stories about my reports, musings about tiny house living and the writing life,  more about the people and places I encounter, and the sounds of nature. 


Donors over $250 will have their names inscribed on special "gratitude panels" on the outside of my Vehicle, for all the world to see.  At the $1000 level you can pick a topic for me to research and write about for my Letters from Earth broadcasts.  (Yes, a group of you can pool your resources to get your issue on my agenda.) At $2500, I create a work of digital art about a topic you choose.  At $3500 you'll have bought me a battery, and you get to design your own square foot in my battery bay door mural "I Get A Charge Out of You."  $5000 donors can choose a destination for me to visit in person, to research, photograph and write about in detail. 

The Impact

  • By writing about bodies and landscape together, Letters from Earth brings together environmental, disability justice, health, women's liberation, and human rights activism, expanding our understanding of accessibility, sustainability, and public health.
  • Through activist art about environmental justice, I'll reach and engage new audiences, and give them ways to take action on the issues I profile.
  • My writing will connect people who don't yet know about each others work, and create links between activists in different movements.
  • I'll bring national attention to many local environmental struggles through personal, poetic stories that will move people.
  • I'll provide action and information links with each broadcast, giving listeners a concrete way to respond, and build broader support for local campaigns and projects.
  • You can become an interest free lender through The Working World
I believe storytelling has the power to restore connection and change how people think.  That transformation begins with imagination and hope, and this is the work of poets.  I believe in the power of conversation, within and between communities, of people listening to each other.  That imagination, hope and connection can bind us together into something new. Into molecules of change.  I’m asking you to help me do my part.


Challenges

  • Urgency!  It's costing my family more than we can afford to maintain the family home where I'm staying.  I need to get moved into my Vehicle and out on the road as soon as possible.  We also need to sell our land in Marlboro, Vermont to cover our expenses.
  • Building a custom, chemically safe tiny house on wheels is a really big and difficult job. I've had to research every single aspect of its design at length, testing and discarding a lot of materials and design options.  Many of the materials, components, and procedures I've chosen are newly developed or just unfamiliar to builders.  This makes it hard for them to price supplies or accurately estimate labor costs.  It's an unusual project, and it's been hard to find construction professionals who are willing to take on the challenge.
  • The rules about where you can park an RV and for how long vary tremendously from place to place, so planning my itinerary requires a lot of research and local help, and I'll need to pay a staff person to coordinate that effort.
  • As a chronically ill person, my energy is unreliable.  Because my needs are complex and constantly changing, I need a diverse and flexible support team able to respond without overtaxing any one person. 
These are all big challenges, but I have a great community, and I'm a very resilient person.  I've already done a lot of amazing things that seemed impossible, including learning to walk again after a stroke--in Cuba!  I'll keep updating you about how I'm resolving these issues throughout the campaign.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to be part of this project besides donating money.  CONTACT US DIRECTLY FOR MORE INFORMATION ABOUT ANY OF THESE OPTIONS.

  • One of the main ones is to SPREAD THE WORD! Use the IndieGoGo share button to tell your friends and networks about Letters from Earth and the Vehicle for Change.
  • Join my team as a Troubadour and commit to sending out messages to your networks every few days throughout the campaign.  We'll provide the content.  All you have to do is share it. LET US KNOW AND WE'LL SIGN YOU UP.
  • Get your business or organization to become a Sponsor by donating cash, goods or services that I need. They'll get their logo on my Vehicle and a lot of exposure. You can ask for us, or give us the contacts and we'll make the pitch.
  • Join my Lender team and make me a long term interest free loan through The Working World.  We're seeking loans of $5000 or more as an alternative to a short term truck loan from a dealer or bank.
  • Join my Ground Team and help find me places where I can park.
  • Connect me with people, organizations and issues I should know about.
  • Once I start broadcasting, tell everyone you know to listen to Letters from Earth.
  • Do you know anyone who might want to buy our family's land in Marlboro, Vermont? It's 20 lovely acres of wooded land with a spring and studio cabin, in a beautiful, progressive and culturally rich area.  Contact me for more information.

Audio Club members will get recordings from my journey--back stories about my reports, musings about tiny house living and the writing life,  more about the people and places I encounter, and the sounds of nature.  
Donors over $250 will have their names inscribed on special "gratitude panels" on the outside of my Vehicle, for all the world to see.  At the $1000 level you can pick a topic for me to research and write about for my Letters from Earth broadcasts.  (Yes, a group of you can pool your resources to get your issue on my agenda.) At $2500, I create a work of digital art about a topic you choose.  At $3500 you'll have bought me a battery, and you get to design your own square foot in my battery bay door mural "I Get A Charge Out of You."  $5000 donors can choose a destination for me to visit in person, to research, photograph and write about in detail.  The Impact


By writing about bodies and landscape together, Letters from Earth brings together environmental, disability justice, health, women's liberation, and human rights activism, expanding our understanding of accessibility, sustainability, and public health.

Through activist art about environmental justice, I'll reach and engage new audiences, and give them ways to take action on the issues I profile. 

My writing will connect people who don't yet know about each others work, and create links between activists in different movements.
I'll bring national attention to many local environmental struggles through personal, poetic stories that will move people.
I'll provide action and information links with each broadcast, giving listeners a concrete way to respond, and build broader support for local campaigns and projects. 

You can become an interest free lender through The Working World 

I believe storytelling has the power to
restore connection and change how people think. 
That transformation begins with imagination and hope, and this is the work
of poets.  I believe in the power of
conversation, within and between communities, of people listening to each
other.  That imagination, hope and
connection can bind us together into something new. Into molecules of change.  I’m asking you to help me do my part. 
 
 
Challenges 
Urgency!  It's costing my family more than we can afford to maintain the family home where I'm staying.  I need to get moved into my Vehicle and out on the road as soon as possible.  We also need to sell our land in Marlboro, Vermont to cover our expenses. 

Building a custom, chemically safe tiny house on wheels is a really big and difficult job. I've had to research every single aspect of its design at length, testing and discarding a lot of materials and design options.  Many of the materials, components, and procedures I've chosen are newly developed or just unfamiliar to builders.  This makes it hard for them to price supplies or accurately estimate labor costs.  It's an unusual project, and it's been hard to find construction professionals who are willing to take on the challenge. 

The rules about where you can park an RV and for how long vary tremendously from place to place, so planning my itinerary requires a lot of research and local help, and I'll need to pay a staff person to coordinate that effort. 

As a chronically ill person, my energy is unreliable.  Because my needs are complex and constantly changing, I need a diverse and flexible support team able to respond without overtaxing any one person.  

 These are all big challenges, but I have a great community, and I'm a very resilient person.  I've already done a lot of amazing things that seemed impossible, including learning to walk again after a stroke--in Cuba!  I'll keep updating you about how I'm resolving these issues throughout the campaign.  
    Other Ways You Can Help There are many ways to be part of this project besides donating money.  CONTACT US DIRECTLY FOR MORE INFORMATION ABOUT ANY OF THESE OPTIONS. 

One of the main ones is to SPREAD THE WORD! Use the IndieGoGo share button to tell your friends and networks about Letters from Earth and the Vehicle for Change. 

Join my team as a Troubadour and commit to sending out messages to your networks every few days throughout the campaign.  We'll provide the content.  All you have to do is share it. LET US KNOW AND WE'LL SIGN YOU UP. 

Get your business or organization to become a Sponsor by donating cash, goods or services that I need. They'll get their logo on my Vehicle and a lot of exposure. You can ask for us, or give us the contacts and we'll make the pitch.

Join my Lender team and make me a long term interest free loan through The Working World.  We're seeking loans of $5000 or more as an alternative to a short term truck loan from a dealer or bank. 

Join my Ground Team and help find me places where I can park. 


Connect me with people, organizations and issues I should know about. 

Once I start broadcasting, tell everyone you know to listen to Letters from Earth.
Do you know anyone who might want to buy our family's land in Marlboro, Vermont? It's 20 lovely acres of wooded land with a spring and studio cabin, in a beautiful, progressive and culturally rich area.  Contact me for more information.

story:
ABOUT THIS PROJECT

- What is the project?

 Mud house design competition_Reinventing the African Mud Hut Together

designers: Valeria Barchiesi, Francesca De Ponte, Sara Parrinello, Ginevra Rapisardi

  Design Statement

 “I na nye yiri” : You will have a house

Houses are always born in a specific culture, of which they are a natural emanation.

In Ghana, since the most ancient of times, the greatest blessing the ancestor's spirits could bestow  upon someone has been “I na nye yiri”  

The need and the desire of having a house unites all people in the world.

Architecture is the tool that satisfies this need through ideas/answers that changes through time and place, as the questions themselves evolve.

The project is a prototype mud house of 100 square meters, that will be built Abetenim village, a small reality near Kumasi.

The design tries to answer to the Gahanian people request of having a comfortable house which could look at a sustainable future with a regard for the tradition.

The idea that is behind the project is to create a house with mud a material considered poor that instead is rich of potential, from the ecological point of view, the economical  and aesthetical ones.

The mud is a traditional construction material of Ghana, and for a long time it has been the material that has characterized  the Ghanaian landscape. But now day the new growing middle class considered this material as something underprivileged, something to avoid.

So  cities as Kumasi are growing in a chaotic and concreted way, the landscape it's losing its feature.  and that's mean for the Gahanian people not just to lose a tradition but also an opportunity to transform and took the advantages of this tradition.

So our challenge is to take part to the Nka project to change this process of gray urban development.

- How did the project come about?

The project is the result of our partecipation to a design competition organised by NKA Foundation in 2014 to 'reinvent the african mud house'. Our design has been selected to be built. Following this NKA offered us the opportunity to collaborate with them and build our design through a 12 week building workshop in Abetenim village, that will start in June 2016.

They are able to cover part of project costs however it is down to us to raise the rest of the money to fund the build. As architecture students  we are extremely fortunate and excited to have the opportunity to design and manage a live project at this stage of our career, however if we do not manage to raise the money the project may not happen! Any contribution it's precious for us!

- Who is Nka Foundation?

NKA Foundation is a registered nonprofit international organisation that exist to benefit underserved communities through focus on the arts and design education, focusing in human capital development.

 They are developing an Arts village in Abetenim which will provide a stable place for creative local people to work, live, learn and share. A place for experimentation in art and architecture looking for a sustainable development of the Gahanian society. For more information about NKA Foundation visit: www.nkafoundation.org

- What is the donated money going towards?

100% of money we receive will go towards cost of materials and wages for local builders and craftspeople.

- Who is the project benefitting? 

As well as the project being an extremely exciting opportunity for us personally, it is a cause that is definitely worthwhile supporting. The living conditions in many of the low income villages of the Ashanti region are extremely poor due to inadequate construction and water damage. This has initiated a local stereotype around mud construction in the region, and a dependence on expensive imported resources for construction which many of the communities cannot afford. The prototype is an opportunity to challenge the stigma surrounding mud architecture and hopes to create an open source design that can be adopted locally and expanded to enable a future of environmentally sustainable and affordable homes.

Any contribution large or small is hugely appreciated to help bring this project to life!

- If you are interested to take part to the workshop!

DATE:  June 8 to August 31, 2016

VENUE: Abetenim near Kumasi in the Ashanti Region  Ghana

COSTS: Food and accommodation 80€/w plus project contribution of 400€ (flight costs are not included).

EVERYBODY CAN PARTICIPATE Architecture students, architects, sustainable practitioners and volunteers from around the world. Students can use the opportunity for internship, personal research or thesis.

The earth architecture workshop is divided into three parts, everyone can participate in one or all three parts, for a minimum of 2 weeks.

PART ONE, WEEK 1-4: Introduction to designing and building with local earth involving site analysis, hands-on experience from site preparation to the foundation level. Includes formwork design and construction.

PART TWO, WEEK 5-8: Poured wall construction

PART THREE, WEEK 9-12: Roofing, fittings and landscaping of the completed unit to blend with the local landscape.

TO APPLY: Contact info@nkafoundation.org / www.nkafoundation.org for application form.

INFO: workshop.abetenim@gmail.com

WORKSHOP LEADERS: Francesca De Ponte (fra.deponte@gmail.com) and Sara Parrinello (sar.parrinello@gmail.com), Ginevra Rapisardi (ginevra.rapisardi@gmail.com)  who are graduates in Architecture at Roma Tre University and are now master's students at Politecnico di Milano.


Thank you

Francesca , Sara , Ginevra

story:
Climate Change At The Equator

The problem with Climate Change is that it is intangible. You can not see, smell or taste carbon. So how can humanity be inspired to act on something that is only evident once the damage is already done?

To begin, we've traveled to a place where the damage is not only unexpected, it is so far advanced that it's rapidly changing the landscape and the living conditions: the equator.

There are 25 mountains on the equator with glaciers. In 25 years, due largely to the effects of human-induced climate change these glaciers will have disappeared forever. 25 mountains. Zero latitude. 25 years. Zero ice. 25zero.


25zero 

The 25zero expedition aims to inspire meaningful action on Climate Change on a global and a local scale. 

Expedition leader Tim Jarvis is a world-renowned adventurer and environmental scientist. The 25zero teams will climb 6 of the #25zero mountains during COP21.

Tim and his core support team will personally climb 3 of these mountains: Carstensz Pyramid in Asia, Mount Stanley in Africa’s Rwenzori Mountains and Chimborazo in South America. Along the way, they will record footage of the devastating effects that Climate Change is having at the equator, and send it directly to the leaders meeting in Paris for COP21 and to global media outlets powerfully highlighting the urgency of the issue.


What is COP21?

COP21 is the annual 'Conference Of The Parties'. 

Every year the countries that want to take action for the climate meet with the aim to achieve a legally binding and universal agreement.

The aim for Paris, 2015 is to keep global warming below 2°C. 

In the 20 years of meetings prior, the global leaders have not reached a significant outcome. It must be different this year.


The Impact

Glaciers are an integral part of life on the equator. Tim and his crew will summit mountains in Indonesia, Africa and South America during #COP21. 

Glaciers atop Carstensz Pyramid in Indonesia are disappearing at a rate of around 7m of thickness per year and aren't expected to be there after 2015. 



In Africa, the Rwenzori Range, that is the source of the Nile river, has decreased in size by 80% in the last century. In the next 25 years, the glaciers will no longer exist.



In Ecuador, the locals mine the glacial ice from Chimborazo to sell at local markets. In 25 years, and potentially even before then, they won't be able to do that, because of the effects that human induced Climate Change will have had on equatorial glaciers.


How You Can Make A Change

In the past, simply talking about Climate Change and asking your local Government members for policy and action would be seen as enough.

Now, that's bare minimum. Talking is important, but action is imperative. By donating to #25zero, you'll be helping us capture footage of these unique glacial environments before they disappear and to record the stories of the people, plants and animals that rely on them for their survival .

Each of the perks offer something in return, from a simple thanks, to a t-shirt and even the piece of mind that your donation is getting at least one image from the mountain to the masses. But it isn't about what you receive in return. After all, by helping combat Climate Change now, you're giving the greatest gift of all; a sustainable planet for future generations. And that's the most important perk of all.

If you can't afford a monetary donation, sign the WWF Australia Petition and help spread the word of #25zero.


Climb With Tim And The Crew


You don't need to travel to Indonesia to climb the mountain; you can do it from home with the #25zero 'virtual climb' App. 

The App empowers you to share the experience of climbing the 25zero mountains with Tim and his teams. Footage, including images, videos and voice logs, will be captured periodically by the climbers, relayed and embedded into the app so you can experience it at the same time.

The App also enables you to choose the difficulty level of the mountain you want to climb. You can undertake your own personal challenge or race friends & colleagues to the summit. Reaching key ‘event points’ on the mountain unlocks interesting stories, facts and footage about the mountains, the people, flora and fauna that live there and how climate change will affect them, and what can be done about it.

Competition is encouraged between participants with the goal to raise money for our charity partner, World Wildlife Fund Australia. The fundraising functionality directs campaign proceeds directly to WWF climate change projects and sharing of the experience via social media.


What Your Donation Achieves

We need resources to ensure the transmission of real time images and messages from the mountains along the equator directly to the world's leaders at COP21 and to global media. This includes:

  • Bandwidth to get images from some of the highest and most remote mountains in the world to a global audience
  • On the ground, in-country support
  • Media mobilisation and logistics
  • Communications equipment costs
  • Messaging via mass media and social media platforms

What If We Don't Reach The Target

If our target isn't reached, we risk the opportunity of sending real time footage that Tim and his core support team capture during the climbs, to the leaders at #COP21 and to global media outlets. 

The biggest risk is that #COP21 does not result in a meaningful climate change agreement. The world’s nations have meet once a year for 20 years and to date not agreed on a way forward. This time must be different.

Compared to this, the risks associated with 25zero are minimal. Climbing mountains involves some risks but the men and women that form the climb teams are experienced and dedicated to the cause. They take responsibility for their actions and believe in trying to set a positive example of what can be done, highlighting the changes that are happening and committing to do something about it.

story:
Hi, I'm Gianfilippo  and I love my dogs.
A problem I often had was to find their food bowl full of ants and ants everywhere.

To solve this problem after  several attempts I created

The double no-ants bowl

So, I made some prototypes in wood and in plastic and after having tested their efficiency my friend Domenico and I decided to produce it with the best plastic  BPA free for human food to make it hygienic, durable, light and economic if produced in large quantities and.....

  

         Our testers

                         

                               

                       The mechanism is very simple:

                             

Just put the food into the central bowl and the drinking water in the bigger bowl. The water by surrounding the food will keep it away from ants, they will not even get close to the bowl.

   


Eureka Bowl size:

    length39 cm,width 25 cm, height 8 cm

Capacity:       

 16 oz. dry food or 35 oz. wet food , 2,5 l. water

A steel bowl that fits the food area is available to reduce the capacity of the bowl to 10 oz. of dry food or 22 oz. of wet food

this is very useful for cats and small dogs and if you don't want to always leave the food available to the pets

         

                              is produced in 4 colors:

                                       

                      

                       

What we need to start the company is the mold to produce the

XXL no-ants Eureka Bowl for big dogs.

So we ask pet lovers and  lovers of useful gadgets to help us realize our goal

Those who support our campaign on INDIEGOGO will be thanked with the bowls corresponding to the  value of the donation made and they will be mentioned in the Wall of Thanks on our Facebook page.

Thank you  and..........................spread the word

                             If your country is not mentioned among those

                         where you can make the shipment please Contact us

         Want to sell the Eureka Bowl Original™ in your store ? Contact us

                                         filppo.bellomare@fastwebnet.it 

Follow us on Facebook

story:
Short Summary

My name is Prince Kwame Agbata and i live and reside in an urban local community called Omandjo Dwenwoho in Accra Ghana, a community cut away from basics amenities like access to good drinking water, drainage systems as well as waste management services.

Over 70,000 youth graduate annually from a local university here in Accra Ghana, myself be one of them didnt want to join the unemployed rising number of youth in my country. I see myself as a shaker, mover and change maker and for that matter, after i lost a best friend to the 3rd June 2015 majot flooding disaster that claim about 215 lives including Mike's, a best friend.... i decided it was finally time to stop the seasonal flooding incidents in my community by considering recycling as a solution to the waste hazards in my community and nation at large as CSIR investigative reports showed that such disaster would have been avoided if the limited  available drainage systems where not engulfed by waste.

This campaign is important to me becuase the death of mike gave me a gift and an opportunity to tackle this problem from the grassroot instead of channeling my anger to the government and complaining. with you help as a contributor, we can reach out to thousands of the younger generation through education on waste management practices as well as introduce an on campus reycling project.

I want to communities like mine in Accra and all over Ghana  from market place to even our beaches which as so enguled with plastic waste become clean and green again. I ebelive educating the younger generation(as Africa holds the highest number of young people than any other continent and that number will double by 2050) as they are the future .



What We Need & What You Get

The coliba project seeks to raise fund to roll out a school project in 25 community schools in Accra Ghana, namely James Town, lapaz and Omandjo Dwenwoho (community in Accra that has been cut off from waste collection services ). The fund is to enable the purchasing of logistics such as waste bins, gloves and tools used for general waste collection and clean up .
1. 50 large waste bins
2. 1000 pieces of gloves and nose masks
3.1000 pieces of waste bags

4. community and on campus education and sensitisation reach out/campaign



These logistics would go a long way to enable us educate students on good waste management and segregation practices as well as alternative use of waste. recyclable waste collected from the schools would be sorted and sold to the recycling companies. Revenues raised from sales will be used to sustain the projects in the schools as well as reach out to more community schools.

At the Community level, this project seeks to educate home owners and citizens at the community level in James Town, Lapaz and Omandjo Dwenwoho on the need of segregation as well as incentivise families and individuals who are able to segregate their waste for us through three(3) packages such as the Coliba cash where low-income families can raise money , coliba School where money raise per the kilos of waste submitted by parents would go into paying a child's fees and Coliba health for health insurance provisions to parents that cant afford them.

We seek to gather 2000 kilos(2tonnes) of waste monthly and make sales to the recycling companies to enable us pay home owners and suppliers as well as sustain the projects in community schools and other community projects like beach clean up aside the education and sensitisation workshops.


The Impact

This project will empower citizens; introduce community and on campus recycling project, satisfy the demand of recycling companies, generate revenue for owners and low-income families as well as protecting the environment for the benefit of all.

This school and community reycling project would be successful becuase we have piloted a community project like this in Lapaz, where we currenlt encourage home owners as well as shop owners and market woment to properly store recyclable waste materials like plastics and bottles and bring them in return for cash. We made this much more easier by providing them waste bags for them to do sorting of the waste they make. this number has risen to 42 community women supply waste to us instead of following the normal practices of dumping them in drainage systems as waste management company services are expensive for them.

what else could be more exciting than keeping your waste sorted and be incentivised for them through recycling? Has this been done somewhere else and been successful?  Yes. Wecyclers.com in nigeria has made is happen and it can hold true here as well.

I encourage you to support us even if you cant contribute by helping us reach out to every invidual soul there , change makers, young, old, friends and all those passionate to see change in the world, most of all environmental change.

Help has share this campaign with with rest of your world and network. Thank you!
story_txt:
Short SummaryMy name is Prince Kwame Agbata and i live and reside in an urban local community called Omandjo Dwenwoho in Accra Ghana, a community cut away from basics amenities like access to good drinking water, drainage systems as well as waste management services.Over 70,000 youth graduate annually from a local university here in Accra Ghana, myself be one of them didnt want to join the unemployed rising number of youth in my country. I see myself as a shaker, mover and change maker and for that matter, after i lost a best friend to the 3rd June 2015 majot flooding disaster that claim about 215 lives including Mike's, a best friend.... i decided it was finally time to stop the seasonal flooding incidents in my community by considering recycling as a solution to the waste hazards in my community and nation at large as CSIR investigative reports showed that such disaster would have been avoided if the limited  available drainage systems where not engulfed by waste.This campaign is important to me becuase the death of mike gave me a gift and an opportunity to tackle this problem from the grassroot instead of channeling my anger to the government and complaining. with you help as a contributor, we can reach out to thousands of the younger generation through education on waste management practices as well as introduce an on campus reycling project.I want to communities like mine in Accra and all over Ghana  from market place to even our beaches which as so enguled with plastic waste become clean and green again. story:
Our Story
 


Welcome to HEMMER Services. We are new on the 'mercury recovery' scene, and so is our fresh and patented technology. However, we are not inexperienced. In fact, we have been recovering environmental mercury for over 20 years. When we realized that we could use our experience on a larger scale, to do our part to help the environment, we created The HEMMER (HEavy Metal and MERcury recovery). Through our activities, we aim to use the latest technologies in order to improve our local ecosystems. Our main purpose is to contract with local and state government across various sectors to cleanse and restore our rivers and reservoirs.


Mercury Facts

Mercury (Hg) is an element that occurs in the environment naturally as a result of human activity. It is a silvery color and the only metal that is liquid at room temperature. It is considered one of the "heavy metals" because of its atomic weight and can be found as number '80' on the periodic table of elements. Mercury can also evaporate to form an odorless, colorless, vapor. Mercury has proved useful for measuring devices such as thermometers, but is toxic to humans and animals.

Research on a northern Wisconsin lake found that as little of one gram of mercury per year was enough to contaminate the lake's entire fish population. When mercury enters the water, it can combine with organic materials to form organic compounds such as methylmercury (MeHg), which is produced mainly by bacteria and is the form that poses the greatest risk to environmental exposure.

The process by which mercury contaminates fish is very complex. Simply put, tiny organisms absorb mercury. Small fish eat the tiny organisms; big fish eat the small fish and so goes the food chain heirarchy. By a process called biomagnification, mercury levels increase as they move up the food chain. Ultimately, mercury levels in humans are the greatest, as we are at the top of the food chain

 

The HEMMER

The HEMMER is the foundation and heart of aquatic restoration. Using proprietary technology, coupled with traditional methods, the HEMMER effectively recovers toxic liquid mercury from waterways in an efficient and safe manner. Cleansing our waters for fish and human consumption.
 

Electromagnetic Field

The HEMMER generates an intense electromagnetic field
creating process known as photoionization and field ionization. This process separates electrons (charge separation) from molecules which 'ionizes' water. Once water has been ionized, it becomes a reliable conductor of electrical current. This creates ideal conditions to introduce electrical charge to objects within the aquatic environment, specifically liquid metal mercury.


Mercury Manipulation

Once liquid mercury has gained an electrical charge, the
mercury gains stronger surface tension, and can be 'pulled' towards an object with an opposing electrical charge.
 

Amalgamate

The HEMMER capitalizes greatly on the natural binding, also known as 'amalgamation', between mercury and gold, copper, and similar metals. The HEMMER has multiple surfaces coated with various mixtures that may include gold or copper. These surfaces are also carrying an opposing electrical charge opposite the polarity of the liquid metal mercury.

Using traditional methods, such as shaped riffles, in combination with the above mentioned techniques, the HEMMER effectively stops the forward progression of mercury almost instantly, including a specially designed collection container that uses gold plated slabs with a wide surface area, that is also electrically charged.

The HEMMER grabs hold of mercury, and refuses to let go!

Our Campaign

Even if we don't reach our goal, the funds you contribute will bring us closer to making this a reality. Every penny can be stretched and used wisely. If this project is successful, then the ripple effect will be enormous. State and federal water agencies across the nation will have their eyes on the success or failure of this project. This is not for us, but for the health of all of humanity.

We are now at the end of a long journey, and we need a shoulder to lean on to get us across that finish line. Not just any 'shoulder', but a community of 'shoulders'. Will you be our shoulder to lean on?

Unlike other campaigns, we are not building 'consumer' products. However, we can offer a special perk directly related to the project. For contributions of $500 or more, you will receive a piece of the HEMMER. Specifically, a 24k gold-plated 'riffle', mounted and engraved, which will be roughly 12" in length.

story:
What its all about:

Los Perros Urban Farming is a small scale market garden located in the city of Malmö in Sweden's South. It was started by us; Buddha Browett and Sofia Reuterving. Buddha is originally from Sydney, Australia and Sofia is from Ånge in the North of Sweden. We both moved to Barcelona in 2007 where we met and lived until 2012 when we decided to pack up and move to Malmö. Of course we brought Stretch with us, our adopted Catalan street dog (mascot and farm namesake), and we now call Malmö our home! Late last year our family grew with our little Cleo, the newest member of the team. 

Los Perros Urban Farming was started in 2015 and we are now entering our 3rd year, making us one of Sweden's First commercial Urban Farms. For the past two seasons we have been farming on 1000m2 and this year we are now expanding to 2500m2. With Buddha's background as a chef we feel that we have the advantage of knowing how to use what we grow to its maximum capability, always sharing tips and tricks of how to use something that we raised from seed. We are firm believers in 'zero waste' and we strive to re-use and compost everything we can. We aim to inspire others to grow by showing that high quality produce can be grown anywhere, especially in an urban environment.

Since we started Los Perros Urban Farming, we have noticed a rising demand for locally grown, vegetables and flowers, grown under organic principles. That's why in 2017 we are expanding to 2500m2, which makes us (apparently) the largest commercial Urban Farm in Sweden. So far we have put everything we have into our farm, and to be able to continue with what we do, we now need your help. With the funds raised by this campaign we will be able to increase our volunteer program, run farm tours, work together with children's educational programs and create a smoother running Urban Farm that benefits the local community.

 

Los Perros Urban Farming and Malmö

Supporters of Los Perros Urban Farming comes in all shapes and sizes, from Michelin Star restaurants to small cafes, from local eateries to the local public. 

And so far..

  • We've delivered and worked together with many of Malmö's favourite restaurants.
  • We've been present at many different Farmers Markets in the city where we have met hundreds of wonderful people and gained a loyal following.
  • Provided a weekly veggie bag, giving us a chance to showcase whats in season. 
  • Created two new herbal infusions. 
  • Had visits from newspapers, magazines and were featured in a book. Giving us a chance to show the abundance that can be grown in Malmö's backyard.
  • Donated vegetables to our local community center.
  • 2016 also saw the introduction and education of volunteers on the farm. 

 

Future plans:

The jump in size from 1000m2 to 2500m2 this year comes with many opportunities. So far we have received interest from different restaurants, cafes, schools, food bloggers/critics, authors and a natural cosmetic company that would like to work together with us, both now and in the coming years. We see opportunities around every corner and look forward to embracing as many as we can handle. Some plans that we have already for this year are:

  • Launching our own chili sauce.
  • Creating more different herbal teas.
  • Being visible at more markets.
  • Supplying to more restaurants.
  • Supplying more veggie bags to our already existing customers and taking on more new customers.
  • Growing a diverse variety of vegetables from around the world and extending the season with the use of row covers and polytunnels.
  • Growing our volunteer and education program.
  • Working together with local schools and kindergartens to teach children where their food comes from and the importance of growing.
  • Giving tours of the Farm. 
  • Creating a designated flower garden, both decretive and edible.
  • Building up our worm farm to help improve our soil and compost our food waste.

​

So what's holding us back?

The jump in land size from 1000m2 to 2500m2 means that we need to improve the way that we work and the tools that we use. In the past we have been using a very basic setup - only small hand tools, which means a lot of our time has been spent on tasks like hand weeding. With better tools our work will become more effective, which would make it possible for us to provide more fresh, organic vegetables to our local community and spend more time on our educational programs.

 

Thats why we need your help.

By donating, you would be helping us to reach our dream of showing that locally produced food is possible to grow right here in Malmö's own backyard. 

Some of the things we need for the farm are: 

  • Weed Sheets:  To keep weed pressure down.
  • Row Covers:  Which would help us to extend the seasons. Vital to our challenging climate.
  • With a 2 Wheel BCS Tractor, we would save days of work spent on turning soil and making beds, saving us both lots of time and lots of muscle aches!
  • Being 'chemical free' means that we need to find creative ways to deter pests. An Insect Net would stop our crops from being eaten and damaged by a range of different insects, flies, bugs and even birds.
  • A Cargo Bike is the greenest way to deliver our vegetables, herbs and flowers. Appreciated by both the environment and our community.

 

     

     

    To Say Thank You For Donating: 

    To show our appreciation for donating towards our farm, we would like to offer you something back. So with the help from some of Malmös best restaurants, cafes, meeting places, food critics, products, food/drinks and of course our very own farm we can offer you to get something back when you donate. 

    If you donate towards Los Perros Urban Farming you have the choice to, as a bonus, get one of our fantastic 'perks' (depending on how much you choose to donate) Maybe it's a cup of locally roasted coffee, your new favorite t-shirt or perhaps even dinner for two at one of Malmö's best restaurants. 

    The amount that you donate goes directly towards helping Los Perros Urban Farming to grow. (The 'Perks' offered are given as a 'Thank You' for the donation and therefore they do not reflect the financial value that they usually come at if you were to buy the product directly). 

    Of course you can also donate towards us without choosing a 'perk' and every euro counts.

     

     

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If it's not possible for you to help out financially, there's still a lot of other ways you could help out and be our heroes too!

    • Share this on social media. Which platform is up to you, maybe it's all of them. Every bit of noise and support that you can help us with, helps, it really does!
    • Volunteer at Los Perros Urban Farming. Come and learn what urban farming is all about. The 2017 season is growing and we are inviting everyone who wants to get their hands dirty. The more help the better. 
    • Follow us on Facebook, Instagram or sign up to our mailing list on our website to stay up to date with what's new and what's coming up.
    • Come and support us at a farmers markets this coming season. 
    • Spread the word, tell your friends, family and loved ones about us and what we are doing.

     

    If you have any questions what so ever, don't hesitate to contact us! 

    #SupportYourLocalUrbanFarmer

     

     

     

    FROM US TO YOU

    THANK YOU!

story:
Short Summary and Impact:

Hi everybody! I’m Marika Roma, I’ve always been passionate about conservation and after my master in Conservation and Evolution at Pisa University I spent 6-months in Uganda as team leader of chimpanzee conservation project.

I sign up to the Master in Primate Conservation at Oxford Brookes University last September and while studying I’ve grown passionate about lemurs due to their endangered status and pet trade.

Thanks to the article from Ross et al. 2011 “Specific Image Characteristics Influence Attitudes about Chimpanzee Conservation and Use as Pets” I have grown interest on how taking photos with wildlife can influence tourists’ perceptions how likely animals are to be considered good pets. Therefore, I decided to investigate this topic with wild lemurs in Madagascar, as this can have major consequences on lemur conservation!

What we need and what you get:

With your help, I will be able to visit four places (selected as areas with higher amount of tourist-lemur photos on-line): Lemur Park, Lemur Island, Nosy Be and Nosy Komba.

I will collect mainly data regarding ring-tailed lemur (Lemur catta), black and white ruffled lemur (Varecia variegata), brown lemur (Eulemur fulvus) and black lemur (Eulemur macaco).

I will stay 10 days in every area and I will collect data on:                         

  • Tourists’ perceptions regarding lemurs (including data on tourists’ nationality and age)
  • Tourists’ interaction with lemurs (positive, neutral and negative)
  • Tourists’ desire to have a pet lemur before and after taking a photo with them

Data will be collected through direct observation and semi-structured interviews.

The influence of taking photos with lemurs on tourists’ feelings is still unexplored and you can be fundamental for the discovery of a potentially underestimated threat to lemurs’ conservation!

All the money I ask funding for, will be used for my subsistence and entry in reserves.

How you can help:

If you can help giving some to this campaign, I will be more than happy to send you monthly updates from the field and first-choice perks (different for every donation amount) with the symbol of this campaign! Moreover, for those donating £100 or more, I would be very glad to cite you officially in my thesis!

If I manage to reach my target, I will donate any extra money to the incredibly active charity “Lemur Love” operating in Madagascar! (http://www.lemurlove.org/)

If you can’t help donating, don’t worry! It would be lovely if you manage to share this campaign on your social media! Thank you so much!!

Italian version
Sommario ed effetti di questa campagna:

Ciao a tutti! Sono Marika Roma, una grande appassionata di conservazione animale! Dopo il mio master in Conservazione ed Evoluzine a Pisa, ho passato 6 mesi in Uganda lavorando come principale assistente di un progetto per la conservazione degli scimpanze’.

Mi sono iscritta al master di Conservazione dei primati all’Universita’ di Oxford Brookes lo scorso Settembre e durante gli studi mi sono appassionata allo studio dei lemuri, principalmemte a causa del loro alto rischio di estinzione e del mercato che li vede commerciati come animali da compagnia.

In seguito all’articolo “Specific Image Characteristics Influence Attitudes about Chimpanzee Conservation and Use as Pets” di Ross et al. 2011, mi sono interessata a come fare foto con lemuri puo’ influenzare le percezioni dei turisti ed in particolare il loro desiderio d’avere un lemure domestico!

Cosa mi serve e cosa ottenete:

Con il vostro aiuto saro’ capace di visitare quattro dei siti con maggior numero di foto rappresentanti lemuri e turisti insieme su internet: Lemur Park, Lemur Island, Nosy Be e Nosy Komba. Mi concentrero' sulla raccolta di dati riguardanti Eulemur fulvus, Eulemur macaco, Lemur catta e Varecia variegata (il lemure nella seguente foto).

Staro’ 10 giorni in ogni posto mentre raccolgo dati riguardanti:

  • Percezioni dei turisti riguardo i lemuri (includendo dati sulla nazionalita’ ed eta’ dei turisti).
  • Interazioni tra lemuri e turisti (positiva, neutrale e negativa).
  • Desiderio dei turisti d’avere un lemure domestico prima e dopo aver fatto un foto con loro.

I dati saranno raccolti tramite osservazioni dirette ed interviste semi-strutturate.

L’influenza che hanno le foto con i lemuri sui sentimenti dei turisti e’ ancora inesplorata e voi potete giocare una parte fondamentale nella scoperta di una nuova e potenzialmente sottostimata minaccia alla conservazione dei lemuri. Tutti i soldi raccolti saranno usati per la mia sussistenza e per l’entrata giornaliera nelle riserve.

Come potete aiutare:

Se potete supportare economicamente il mio progetto, sarò’ felice di mandarvi aggiornamenti mensili riguardo il mio lavoro sul campo e premi (differenti per ogni ammontare donato) con il logo della campagna! Coloro che doneranno 100£ o più’ saranno anche citati ufficialmente tra i supporter della mia tesi.

Se riuscirò’ a raggiungere e superare l’ammontare di cui necessito, donerò’ tutti i soldi in più’ all'incredibilmente attiva charity “Lemur Love” operante in Madagascar! (http://www.lemurlove.org/).

Se non potete contribuire economicamente a questo progetto, vi sarei incredibilmente grata se riusciste a condividere la mia campagna sui vostri social media! Grazie mille!!
story_txt:
Short Summary and Impact:Hi everybody! I’m Marika Roma, I’ve always been passionate about conservation and after my master in Conservation and Evolution at Pisa University I spent 6-months in Uganda as team leader of chimpanzee conservation project.I sign up to the Master in Primate Conservation at Oxford Brookes University last September and while studying I’ve grown passionate about lemurs due to their endangered status and pet trade.Thanks to the article from Ross et al. 2011 “Specific Image Characteristics Influence Attitudes about Chimpanzee Conservation and Use as Pets” I have grown interest on how taking photos with wildlife can influence tourists’ perceptions how likely animals are to be considered good pets. Therefore, I decided to investigate this topic with wild lemurs in Madagascar, as this can have major consequences on lemur conservation!What we need and what you get:With your help, I will be able to visit four places (selected as areas with higher amount of tourist-lemur photos on-line): Lemur Park, Lemur Island, Nosy Be and Nosy Komba.I will collect mainly data regarding ring-tailed lemur (Lemur catta), black and white ruffled lemur (Varecia variegata), brown lemur (Eulemur fulvus) and black lemur (Eulemur macaco).I will stay 10 days in every area and I will collect data on:                         
Tourists’ perceptions regarding lemurs (including data on tourists’ nationality and age)
Tourists’ interaction with lemurs (positive, neutral and negative)
Tourists’ desire to have a pet lemur before and after taking a photo with them
Data will be collected through direct observation and semi-structured interviews.The influence of taking photos with lemurs on tourists’ feelings is still unexplored and you can be fundamental for the discovery of a potentially underestimated threat to lemurs’ conservation!All the money I ask funding for, will be used for my subsistence and entry in reserves.How you can help:If you can help giving some to this campaign, I will be more than happy to send you monthly updates from the field and first-choice perks (different for every donation amount) with the symbol of this campaign! Moreover, for those donating £100 or more, I would be very glad to cite you officially in my thesis!If I manage to reach my target, I will donate any extra money to the incredibly active charity “Lemur Love” operating in Madagascar! (http://www.lemurlove.org/) If you can’t help donating, don’t worry! It would be lovely if you manage to share this campaign on your social media! Thank you so much!!Italian versionSommario ed effetti di questa campagna:Ciao a tutti! Sono Marika Roma, una grande appassionata di conservazione animale! I dati saranno raccolti tramite osservazioni dirette ed interviste semi-strutturate.L’influenza che hanno le foto con i lemuri sui sentimenti dei turisti e’ ancora inesplorata e voi potete giocare una parte fondamentale nella scoperta di una nuova e potenzialmente sottostimata minaccia alla conservazione dei lemuri. Tutti i soldi raccolti saranno usati per la mia sussistenza e per l’entrata giornaliera nelle riserve.Come potete aiutare:Se potete supportare economicamente il mio progetto, sarò’ felice di mandarvi aggiornamenti mensili riguardo il mio lavoro sul campo e premi (differenti per ogni ammontare donato) con il logo della campagna! Coloro che doneranno 100£ o più’ saranno anche citati ufficialmente tra i supporter della mia tesi.Se riuscirò’ a raggiungere e superare l’ammontare di cui necessito, donerò’ tutti i soldi in più’ all'incredibilmente attiva charity “Lemur Love” operante in Madagascar! (http://www.lemurlove.org/).Se non potete contribuire economicamente a questo progetto, vi sarei incredibilmente grata se riusciste a condividere la mia campagna sui vostri social media! Grazie mille!!

story:
A Surfrider Foundation Porto precisa da tua ajuda para conseguir hoje, criar as condições necessárias para que a população no futuro possa usufruir de forma segura de todo o património natural sobre o qual vivemos.

A pressão a que estão sujeitas as praias e rios bem, como a exposição dos surfistas e utilizadores, justifica uma campanha estruturada de acompanhamento por parte da Surfrider Foundation no Porto.

Com o apoio individual de cada um, conseguiremos atingir o nosso objectivo!
 

Quem somos?

A Surfrider Foundation Porto, é uma representação local da Surfrider Foundation Europe, Organização Não Governamental de Ambiente, composta unicamente por voluntários e dedicada à proteção e valorização pela vivência dos oceanos, ondas e praias, através de uma poderosa rede de ativistas que se estende por todo o mundo.
 

A Qualidade da Água “Balnear”

Os desportos aquáticos estão a tornar-se cada vez mais populares, sendo em alguns casos o alicerce do turismo e da hotelaria. Este tipo de atividades é tendencialmente praticado durante todo o ano em áreas que podem, ou não, ser de uso balnear. A Surfrider Foundation Europe defende que a saúde e segurança deste grupo de pessoas (surfistas ou outro tipo de utilizadores, como banhistas) deve ser garantida.

A qualidade das águas consideradas como balneares é condicionada e definida pela sua envolvente. As praias do Porto e Matosinhos estão expostas a fontes de poluição (ameaças) de diferentes naturezas, que se distinguem pela forma como atuam sobre a qualidade da água.

Dado o historial da praia e acontecimentos de 2016 e 2017, iremos focar a monitorização em indicadores bacteriológicos (Escherichia coli e Enterococos intestinais).
 

Amostragem

A recolha das amostras de água para análise será realizada no mar que banha as praia de Matosinhos, Azurara e Vila Nova de Gaia, perto de onde normalmente existem surfistas. Na perspetiva de obter resultados comparáveis, pretende-se garantir as mesmas condições na amostragem, no que se refere à profundidade (mais perto possível da água que o surfista/utilizador pode ingerir), à maré e à localização.
 

Quando?

As recolhas serão feitas ao longo de 52 semanas após o final da campanha de crowdfundig, abrangendo assim as 4 estações do ano. Será feito um esforço para que sejam realizadas sempre no mesmo dia da semana.
 

Análise em Laboratório Independente

As amostram serão analisadas por um laboratório independente, acreditado pelo IPAC – Instituto Português de Acreditação, e considerado apto pela ERSAR - Entidade Reguladora de Águas e Resíduos.

Os ensaios atrás descritos estão incluídos no âmbito da acreditação. Precisamos da tua ajuda!

story:
Aloha from the Big Island of Hawaii! I’m Tim Mann.

My wife Susanne and I, and our four children Victor, Jack, Lucky, and Rose, are building sailing fishing boats that will change the world and clean up our oceans. We're calling the first of these boats Splash, and this is The Splash Project. The purpose of the project is to build the first boat and demonstrate the viability of the concept to the world (WE know it works!).

Here's what these boats will do, and why they are valuable to you and the rest of the world:

1. These boats catch fish but don't need diesel fuel to operate; they don't pollute our planet, and they don't increase global warming the way that current factory-fishing methods do. The wind they use is not only CLEAN, it's also FREE! They look like this:

2. The fishing methods we use eliminate the tragic waste of "bycatch", where as much as 6 pounds of fish and other marine life is killed by motorized fishing boats for each pound that lands on your table. Seals, dolphins, turtles, and non-targeted species of fish are routinely caught, killed, then dumped over the side. Here's what we'll be eliminating with our boats:

3. The fishing methods we use also eliminate the destruction of marine habitat and life caused by net-fishing, especially factory trawling, which drags huge nets with steel cables and steel plates directly over the ocean floor. We will replace what you see below with sailboats that don't pollute, don't cause global warming, don't create bycatch, and don't waste our precious ocean resources:

4. Our boats run on wind, not diesel; and when the high cost of fuel is taken out of the cost of fish, your local ocean fish prices could go down to half what they are now. You might feel better about eating ocean fish if they cost half as much and came from a non-polluting fishing boat that didn't create any wasteful bycatch. That's a direct benefit for you.

We're qualified and prepared to do this:

I've built boats since I was 16, and designed and built my first sailing fishing boat, the 56-foot Tropic Bird, in 1978. I fished Tropic Bird commercially from 1979 to 1995 in Hawaii and the Marshall Islands, made good money fishing, and learned firsthand how viable the concept of sailing fishing boats was.

As a professional boatbuilder, I've built many large boats. The whole family (Susanne, Victor, Jack Lucky, and Rose) has been working in the boat shop learning how to use the tools, the glues and fiberglass, and how to work in wood. We have our own boat shop. We have a local source of sustainable lumber in log form, and our own sawmill to saw it into boat-building lumber. We have boat shop equipment that includes a 3-ton forklift, a 10-ton crane, and $60,000 worth of hand and shop tools.

We need your help to do this:

They say it takes a village to raise a child; well, in Polynesia where we live, it takes a village to build a boat. Everyone’s involved, from the smallest child who fetches coconut fronds to shade the canoe from the sun, to the master canoe builder who prays among the trees in the forest for days before selecting the one to become the canoe.

We’re the same. We may be experienced boat builders and blue water sailors, but we still need our village. Especially for this project; because it’s the most ambitious one we’ve ever undertaken. It’s truly the start of a blue-green revolution in the way we do things on the ocean! We’re not just making a new iPhone app or electronic gadget; we’re building a BOAT!

That’s why we need your help. Funding this project will allow us to finish Splash as much as a year or two sooner than if funded her all ourselves. We'll build her anyway, it will just take us a lot longer without funding. We think this is important for the world to see as soon as possible.

Once we're fully funded, we'll have the boat in the water 9 months later. Just like a baby!

    The Risks & Challenges Of The Project

    • For you? Maybe having to wait a little longer than you'd like for your perk, if it's one of those that involve sailing on Splash. We do have to get her finished and in the water before we can take you sailing on her, take you on a surf charter, or teach you how to fish Hawaiian-style.
    • For us? That we don't get adequately funded, and have to fund Splash out of our own pockets. Big deal; it'll take us longer. But this puts off the positive change this boat could make in the world until some time in the future, and that would be a shame.
    • Other risks and challenges? Nothing I haven't successfully dealt with before on any of the 25-odd boats I've built over the last 45 years. And where in the past I've always built boats by myself, now I've got five solid and competent partners in my wife Susanne and my four children. We'll get her done in record time.

    What We Need & What You Get

    • The $65,000 we're asking to fund will purchase all the supplies, materials, hardware, and equipment for the first Splash: the lumber and plywood, the epoxy glue and fiberglass; the nails, screws, bolts, and other fasteners; the mast, turnbuckles, and rigging wire; all the line (what land people call "rope"); the anchors and anchor chain; the refrigeration equipment for the fish hold; the batteries, electrical system and wiring; the radar, fish-finder, and VHF radio; and other things too numerous to list.
    • We're contributing all the labor, the overhead, the insurance, the band-aids, the water cooler for the shop, and the wear and tear on all our shop tools. If we built this boat for a boat shop client, we'd charge them $150,000; so our contribution is worth $85,000; more than what we're asking for in funding.
    • If we don't reach our entire goal, we'll just have to come up with the balance of funding needed by ourselves; and finishing the boat will take a little longer.

    Our Awesome Perks For You:

    Check them out; they range all the way from "you get our sincere thanks" (for ten bucks) on up to a week of sailing on Splash, with all meals cooked for you, craft wines and beers, and your own personal Hawaiian tour and lore guide; on up to owning 20% of the boat!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute your green energy ($), you can still be a big help to the project:

    • Go to The Splash Project website and sign up for our free weekly newsletter in the right hand column; and get your friends signed up if the project interests them. Spreading the word about this opportunity is just as valuable as the funding is!
    • Also please use the Indiegogo share tools!

    Any Questions? Email Tim at skipper@newageofsail.com, email Susanne at firstmate@newageofsail.com, or visit our website: https://newageofsail.com

    With Warm Aloha from Tim, Susanne, Victor, Jack, Lucky, and Rose

If you can't contribute your green energy ($), you can still be a big help to the project:
