story:
ESTA CAMPAÑA ESTA TRADUCIDA AL ESPAÑOL  ABAJO

                                                                We are


WHAT ABOUT YOU?


What does the ocean mean to you?
What do you know about it?
Are you curious about the ocean?
So are we! and we believe understanding marine ecosystems
and its enigmatic life is the key to transform
the valorization of our oceans, and the first step
towards its conservation!

The idea of Amazona divers was born from our personal desire to see the change. In our country, Venezuela, the current political system paradoxically does not prioritize education and the quest for knowledge. Our generation was unluckily enough to live how the incentives for education and research diminished year by year in schools and universities, leaving the current generation of students with nothing but a distorted “educational” system, which very last priority is to create critical and educated minds. The social reality of Venezuela is just a consequence of such system. We are responsible for the change! We need to be the change! 

This is our best reason to create AMAZONA divers, to cultivate fresh knowledge and engage others in the subject we love the most: the ocean!

We are a team of two Venezuelan women who actively decided to set aside our current state of life and get underwater! empathy and different EDUCATION is our goal, now we want to  get deeper and make it our profession. We are women of the world, travelers, dreamers, passionate about life.

We want AMAZONA diver for anyone that is curious about the underwater world, anyone that wants to learn about its complex systems and how we relate to them, anyone that has found their passion while being immersed, and anyone that ever thought that diving can be more than a passion,  a life.  

 Our project is sincere, simple and has a long-term vision which involves you!

We want more people to get closer to marine life, understand it from a fresh new perspective, enjoying its complexity, appreciate its value and get inspired to  jump in and discover the amazing underwater world!

How?

While completing our  professional diving training we will combine our  day-to-day underwater experience with our diverse professional skills to  create a digital channel -Open source- where you and many others can  connect and engage our shared passion: the ocean! we will explore sea life through stories, animations, infographics, podcasts, photos, articles, theater, interviews and a bunch of great resources designed and produced by us, and  made ​​available to everyone from        0 to 100 years and surely free!

Where?

We will feature their inspiring stories in our site to spread their efforts towards conservation and encourage others to get deep. We will create a new way of experiencing the underwater world through the ‘digital senses’, taking you with us in this experience as we get wet and deepen our underwater knowledge.

                                                

  

For us, creating AMAZONADIVER.net is only the beginning.

Our long term vision is to use our content to promote marine educational theater workshops in schools and coastal communities all over Central and South America,  to reach places that are still quite unreachable for the digital age and, ironically, are the ones that need to be Reached!

We found our reason for DEEP!
Now we have to encourage others  to get involved!


                   

                                                       Diversity is the key!

By mixing our experience and talent we will produce the valuable resources that will engage you and others to dream underwater! Want to know more  about us and what we have done!?

                   We are grateful for your support!

Your donations will help us manage the costs of our technical diving trainning and, by keeping ourselves submerged and actively discovering the ocean, we can engage full time in innovating and producing new material that will take you and many others in a journey of aquatic knowledge and marine educational theater workshops in schools.

                                About our Perks!



Support us and enjoy your favorite T-shirt!


Choice your favorite stiker!



You can do a lot to us!
Join us!
There are plenty of ways to get involved

For us support is not uniquely about economic means, advertisement and  social networking can help us cover what would seems beyond reach. So, if  you are passionate about ocean life and believe AMAZONA's can make a  difference in how we understand it, if you're curious about the subaquatic world and thirsty for fresh and creative knowledge, if you think the stories of  AMAZONA's can inspire and push others into the water, if you feel like one of  us, then with your support we can make this happen!

Follow us, like us, share us with your network and help us go deeper!  It will only take you a minute to share your opinion about the project  with the network ...  Here are some nice tweets that you can spread:
-There's a different way to feel the ocean, you can also inspire :)
-Amazona Diver and how each can change the ocean.
-You Can help Amazona Diver and also get a sensational great perks for your type.
Twitter: https://twitter.com/Amazonadivers
Facebook:https://www.facebook.com/pages/Amazona-Divers/424292394395936?ref=hl

 Nosotras Somos


                                             ¿ Qué significa para ti el Océano?
                                                  ¿Sabes como influyes en él?
                                                  ¿ Y cómo influye él en tí?

Bienvenido a Amazona Diver, nosotras creemos que la comprensión de los ecosistemas marinos y su vida enigmática es la clave para transformar el valor que le damos a los océanos, y el primer paso para su conservación!!
La idea de Amazona Divers nació de nuestro deseo personal de ver el cambio en nuestro país Venezuela, donde el sistema político actual, paradójicamente no prioriza en la Educación y la búsqueda del conocimiento. Por desgracia año tras año disminuyen los incentivos para la educación y la investigación en las Escuelas y Universidades, dejando a la actual generación de estudiantes con nada más que un sistema " educativo" distorsionado, el cual, lo último que consigue es formar mentes críticas y educadas. La realidad social de Venezuela es sólo una consecuencia de tal sistema. Somos responsables del cambio! 

Tenemos que ser el cambio!

Esta es la razón por la que creamos Amazona Divers, para cultivar el conocimiento  y comprometer a otros en lo que más amamos: El océano.

Somos un equipo de dos mujeres venezolanas que decidimos activamente dejar de lado nuestra vida cotidiana para ser parte del cambio! Empatizar a traves de una  Educación diferente es nuestro objetivo. Somos mujeres del mundo, Viajeras, Soñadoras y Apasionadas por la vida.

Queremos ser AMAZONA DIVERS, para alcanzar a muchas personas y despertar en ellos la curiosidad por el mundo submarino, el deseo de  aprender sobre sus complejos sistemas y cómo nos relacionamos con ellos desde una perspectiva nueva y fresca, disfrutando de su complejidad, apreciando su valor y obteneniendo inspiración para saltar y descubrir el maravilloso mundo submarino!

Nuestro proyecto es sincero, sencillo y tiene una visión a largo plazo, que quiere implicarte !

¿Cómo?

Durante la realización de nuestro entrenamiento de buceo profesional
combinaremos nuestra experiencia bajo el agua en el día a día con nuestras diversas habilidades profesionales para crear un canal digital, (página web), donde todos  podamos conectarnos, comprometernos y compartir esta pasión: El Océano! Vamos a explorar la vida marina a través de historias, animaciones, infografías , podcasts, fotos, artículos, teatro de las emociones, entrevistas y muchos otros recursos diseñados y producidos por nosotros, y puestos a disposición de todas las personas de 0 a 100 años de forma gratuita!

¿Dónde?

En nuestra Web presentaremos las historias inspiradoras de grandes mujeres y hombres que exploran el océano en la busqueda de un reconocimiento, para difundir sus esfuerzos en pro de la conservación y animar a otros a mantenerse sumergidos. Vamos a crear una nueva forma de experimentar el mundo submarino a través de los sentidos, que te llevará con nosotros en esta experiencia, y a profundizar en nuestro conocimiento subacuatico.

                                                

  

Para nosotras crear AMAZONADIVER.net es apenas el principio.

Nuestra visión a largo plazo es usar nuestro contenido para Promover Talleres de Educacion Ambiental a traves del Teatro de las Emociones en las escuelas y comunidades costeras de Centro y Sudamérica, para llegar a lugares donde la era digital es casi inaccesible.  

¡Nosotras hemos encontrado un camino para generar el Cambio!

¡Ahora queremos animarte a que formes parte de él!


¡En nuestro equipo la Diversidad es La Clave!

Combinando nuestras experiencias y talentos, vamos a producir valiosos recursos que te llevarán a conocer el mundo subacuatico .   ¿Quieres saber más sobre nosotras y lo que haremos? 

¡Estamos más que agradecidas por tu apoyo!

Tu donación nos ayudará a cubrir los gastos de material técnico para el entrenamiento y realización de la página web y nos permitirá mantenernos sumergidas descubriendo activamente el océano, para dedicarle todo nuestro tiempo en crear, innovar y producir nuevo material con el cual los envolveremos a todos en una jornada de conocimiento subacuático, así como la elaboración de talleres de educación ambiental a través del teatro de las emociones en escuelas de  las costas de  América Central y Sur américa. 

¡Mira las recompensas que hemos preparado para agradecer tu colaboración!



¡Apóyanos y disfruta de tu camiseta favorita!

¡Aquí tienes una selección pegatinas, elige tú favorita!



¡Tú puedes hacer mucho por Nosotras!
¡Únete a nuestro proyecto!!!
¡Hay muchas maneras de involucrarte!
Para Nosotras el apoyo no sólo es económico, Difundir nuestro proyecto en tus redes sociales nos ayudará  a llegar más lejos.

Entonces, si sientes pasión por la vida marina y crees que Amazona Diver puede generar un cambio en la manera de entenderla, Si tienes curiosidad acerca del mundo subacuático y tienes sed de conocimientos y aprendizajes creativos, si crees que el proyecto Amazona  va a inspirar y empujar a sumergirse, si te identificas con nuestra idea, Entonces tu apoyo hará esto posible.

Síguenos, dale like, compártenos en tus redes sociales y ayúdanos a llegar más profundo,Sólo te llevará un minuto compartir tu opinión acerca del proyecto Amazona Diver. 
Aquí te ofrecemos algunas buenas ideas de tweets  que puedes compartir:

 -Hay un modo diferente de sentir el océano, tu también puedes inspirarte :)
-Amazona Diver y todos podemos hacer un buen cambio para el océano!.
- Puedes ayudar a Amazona Divers y ademas recibir excelentes recompensas.
  • Twitter: https://twitter.com/Amazonadivers
  • Facebook:https://www.facebook.com/pages/Amazona-Divers/424292394395936?ref=hl
story_txt:
ESTA CAMPAÑA ESTA TRADUCIDA AL ESPAÑOL  ABAJO
                                                                We are


WHAT ABOUT YOU?


What does the ocean mean to you?What do you know about it?Are you curious about the ocean?So are we! and we believe understanding marine ecosystemsand its enigmatic life is the key to transformthe valorization of our oceans, and the first steptowards its conservation!





The idea of Amazona divers was born from our personal desire to see the change. In our country, Venezuela, the current political system paradoxically does not prioritize education and the quest for knowledge. Our generation was unluckily enough to live how the incentives for education and research diminished year by year in schools and universities, leaving the current generation of students with nothing but a distorted “educational” system, which very last priority is to create critical and educated minds. The social reality of Venezuela is just a consequence of such system. We are responsible for the change! We need to be the change! This is our best reason to create AMAZONA divers, to cultivate fresh knowledge and engage others in the subject we love the most: the ocean!We are a team of two Venezuelan women who actively decided to set aside our current state of life and get underwater! empathy and different EDUCATION is our goal, now we want to  get deeper and make it our profession. We are women of the world, travelers, dreamers, passionate about life.
We want AMAZONA diver for anyone that is curious about the underwater world, anyone that wants to learn about its complex systems and how we relate to them, anyone that has found their passion while being immersed, and anyone that ever thought that diving can be more than a passion,   a life.  


 Our project is sincere, simple and has a long-term vision which involves you!

We want more people to get closer to marine life, understand it from a fresh new perspective, enjoying its complexity, appreciate its value and get inspired to   jump in and discover the amazing underwater world!
How?
While completing our  professional diving training we will combine our  day-to-day underwater experience with our diverse professional skills to   create a digital channel -Open source- where you and many others can   connect and engage our shared passion: the ocean! we will explore sea life through stories, animations, infographics, podcasts, photos, articles, theater, interviews and a bunch of great resources designed and produced by us, and   made ​​available to everyone from        0 to 100 years and surely free!
Where?



We will feature their inspiring stories in our site to spread their efforts towards conservation and encourage others to get deep. We will create a new way of experiencing the underwater world through the ‘digital senses’, taking you with us in this experience as we get wet and deepen our underwater knowledge.


                                                
  




For us, creating AMAZONADIVER.net is only the beginning.
Our long term vision is to use our content to promote marine educational theater workshops in schools and coastal communities all over Central and South America,   to reach places that are still quite unreachable for the digital age and, ironically, are the ones that need to be Reached!




We found our reason for DEEP!Now we have to encourage others   to get involved!



                   
                                                       Diversity is the key!
By mixing our experience and talent we will produce the valuable resources that will engage you and others to dream underwater! Want to know more   about us and what we have done!?




                   We
are grateful for your support!

Your donations will help us manage the costs of our technical diving trainning and, by keeping ourselves submerged and actively discovering the ocean, we can engage full time in innovating and producing new material that will take you and many others in a journey of aquatic knowledge and marine educational theater workshops in schools.


                                About our Perks!






Support us and enjoy your favorite T-shirt!


Choice your favorite stiker!






You can do a lot to us!Join us!There are plenty of ways to get involved







For us support is not uniquely about economic means, advertisement and   social networking can help us cover what would seems beyond reach. So, if   you are passionate about ocean life and believe AMAZONA's can make a   difference in how we understand it, if you're curious about the subaquatic world and thirsty for fresh and creative knowledge, if you think the stories of   AMAZONA's can inspire and push others into the water, if you feel like one of   us, then with your support we can make this happen!


Follow us, like us, share us with your network and help us go deeper!  It will only take you a minute to share your opinion about the project   with the network ...  Here are some nice tweets that you can spread:


-There's a different way to feel the ocean, you can also inspire :)-Amazona Diver and how each can change the ocean.-You Can help Amazona Diver and also get a sensational great perks for your type.


Twitter: https://twitter.com/AmazonadiversFacebook:https://www.facebook.com/pages/Amazona-Divers/424292394395936?ref=hl



 Nosotras Somos


                                             ¿ Qué significa para ti el Océano?
                                                  ¿Sabes como influyes en él?
                                                  ¿ Y cómo influye él en tí?

Bienvenido a Amazona Diver, nosotras creemos que la comprensión de los ecosistemas marinos y su vida enigmática es la clave para transformar el valor que le damos a los océanos, y el primer paso para su conservación!!
La idea de Amazona
Divers nació de nuestro deseo personal de ver el cambio en nuestro
país Venezuela, donde el sistema político actual, paradójicamente no
prioriza en la Educación y la búsqueda del conocimiento. Por
desgracia año tras año disminuyen los incentivos para la educación
y la investigación en las Escuelas y Universidades, dejando a la
actual generación de estudiantes con nada más que un sistema "
educativo" distorsionado, el cual, lo último que consigue es formar mentes críticas y educadas. La realidad social de Venezuela es
sólo una consecuencia de tal sistema. Somos responsables del cambio! 
Tenemos que ser el cambio!
Esta es la razón
por la que creamos Amazona Divers, para cultivar el conocimiento  y comprometer a otros en lo que más amamos: El océano.

Somos un equipo de
dos mujeres venezolanas que decidimos activamente dejar de lado
nuestra vida cotidiana para ser parte del cambio! Empatizar a traves de una  Educación diferente es nuestro objetivo. Somos mujeres del mundo, Viajeras,
Soñadoras y Apasionadas por la vida.

Queremos ser AMAZONA
DIVERS, para alcanzar a muchas personas y despertar en ellos la curiosidad por el mundo submarino, el deseo de  aprender sobre sus complejos sistemas y cómo nos relacionamos
con ellos desde una
perspectiva nueva y fresca, disfrutando de su complejidad, apreciando
su valor y obteneniendo inspiración para saltar y descubrir el
maravilloso mundo submarino!
Nuestro proyecto es sincero, sencillo y tiene una visión a largo plazo, que quiere implicarte !

¿Cómo?


Durante la
realización de nuestro entrenamiento de buceo profesionalcombinaremos nuestra experiencia bajo el agua en el día a día con
nuestras diversas habilidades profesionales para crear un canal
digital, (página web), donde todos  podamos conectarnos, comprometernos y
compartir esta pasión: El Océano! Vamos a explorar la vida
marina a través de historias, animaciones, infografías , podcasts,
fotos, artículos, teatro de las emociones, entrevistas y muchos
otros recursos diseñados y producidos por nosotros, y puestos a
disposición de todas las personas de 0 a 100 años de forma
gratuita!

¿Dónde?

En nuestra Web presentaremos las historias inspiradoras de grandes mujeres y hombres que exploran el océano en la busqueda de un reconocimiento, para difundir sus
esfuerzos en pro de la conservación y animar a otros a mantenerse
sumergidos. Vamos a crear una nueva forma de experimentar el mundo
submarino a través de los sentidos, que te llevará con
nosotros en esta experiencia, y a profundizar en nuestro conocimiento
subacuatico.

                                                
  
Para nosotras crear AMAZONADIVER.net es apenas el principio.


Nuestra visión a
largo plazo es usar nuestro contenido para Promover Talleres de
Educacion Ambiental a traves del Teatro de las Emociones en las
escuelas y comunidades costeras de Centro y Sudamérica, para llegar
a lugares donde la era digital es casi inaccesible.  


¡Nosotras hemos encontrado un camino para generar el Cambio!
¡Ahora queremos animarte a que formes parte de él!






¡En nuestro equipo la Diversidad es La Clave!
Combinando nuestras experiencias y talentos, vamos a producir valiosos recursos que te llevarán a conocer el mundo subacuatico .   ¿Quieres saber más sobre nosotras y lo que haremos? 
¡Estamos más que agradecidas por tu apoyo!
Tu donación nos ayudará a cubrir los gastos de material técnico para el entrenamiento y realización de la página web y nos permitirá mantenernos sumergidas descubriendo activamente el océano, para dedicarle todo nuestro tiempo en crear, innovar y producir nuevo material con el cual los envolveremos a todos en una jornada de conocimiento subacuático, así como la elaboración de talleres de educación ambiental a través del teatro de las emociones en escuelas de  las costas de  América Central y Sur américa. 
¡Mira las recompensas que hemos preparado para agradecer tu colaboración!




¡Apóyanos y disfruta de tu camiseta favorita!





¡Aquí tienes una selección pegatinas, elige tú favorita!


¡Tú puedes hacer mucho por Nosotras!¡Únete a nuestro proyecto!!!¡Hay muchas maneras de involucrarte!Para Nosotras el apoyo no sólo es económico, Difundir nuestro proyecto en tus redes sociales nos ayudará  a llegar más lejos.
Entonces, si sientes pasión por la vida marina y crees que Amazona Diver puede generar un cambio en la manera de entenderla, Si tienes curiosidad acerca del mundo subacuático y tienes sed de conocimientos y aprendizajes creativos, si crees que el proyecto Amazona  va a inspirar y empujar a sumergirse, si te identificas con nuestra idea, Entonces tu apoyo hará esto posible.
Síguenos, dale like, compártenos en tus redes sociales y ayúdanos a llegar más profundo,Sólo te llevará un minuto compartir tu opinión acerca del proyecto Amazona Diver. 
Aquí te ofrecemos algunas buenas ideas de tweets  que puedes compartir:


 -Hay un modo diferente de sentir el océano, tu también puedes inspirarte :)-Amazona Diver y todos podemos hacer un buen cambio para el océano!.- Puedes ayudar a Amazona Divers y ademas recibir excelentes recompensas.


Twitter: https://twitter.com/Amazonadivers


Facebook:https://www.facebook.com/pages/Amazona-Divers/424292394395936?ref=hl

story:
Better Globe

We are a Norwegian based company operating since 2006.

A Holistic and Sustainable Social Entrepreneurship Where YOU also Profit on your Donations.

We are active in Kenya and Uganda. Treeplanting, Microfinancing and Education projects.

Better Globe Forestry Ltd. is a very highly respected forestry company in Kenya.
The company has over 100,000 Hectares of land for tree planting in 3 different areas.
Better Globe is an expert in tree planting in semi arid and arid land (ASAL) and  therefore are the pioneers of changing the landscape “From Dryland to Greenland” in Kenya.

The company plants high quality tropical mahogany trees, which grow in dry lands and therefore do not participate in occupying the land where people can grow food. At the same time, when transforming dry land to green land, many poor people will be able to make a living and will be forever grateful to Better Globe for helping them to eradicate poverty.

Today we have more than 15000 people around the world that are our customers. BUT WE NEED MANY MORE.
Our customers purchase TREES.

So far we have planted more than 500,000 trees, financed 5 schools in Kenya and Uganda and given microfinance to 2000 families in Kenya.

If you want to claim the profit from trees that will be bought with your money; send me an e mail with your name, address, e mail, phone number, date of birth and the reference number of your donation. I will register the trees in your name and send you the log in details for your personal web page in Better Globe.
This must be completed immediately after your donation has been made.


What We Need & What You Get

We need people to buy trees or to donate money to plant trees.

The trees you buy or donate will be yours for 20 years, and Better Globe Forestry will pay you back with interest. Annually.

1 tree costs € 17 and will pay you back € 208,25 back starting from year 4 after the purchase.
Net profit: € 191,25

Better Globe Forestry takes care of the trees you buy for 20 years from the date of purchase. From the fifth to the twentieth year you get paid 15 percent profit on your Better Globe trees. The 20th year you will receive 10 times the retail price.

If you buy 1 tree at 17 Euros, your profit will be as follows:

€ 17 x 15 % = € 2.55 x 15 years = € 38 in total.
+ € 17 x 10 (in year twenty) € 170
- € 17 (retail price) € 17
= Total Net Profit € 191


To give you some idea of what kind of profit you will receive by buying more trees,

Product purchase
 Cost Total Net Profit
10 trees  € 170  € 1,910
50 trees  € 850  € 9,550
100 trees  € 1,700  € 19,100
1,000 trees  € 17,000  € 191,000


The Better Globe trees that are planted are a mix of Acacia Senegal (gum arabic) and Mukau (tropical maghoni hardwood).

The money that is paid back to you can be withdrawn to any bank in the world or reinvested in more trees. If you do not claim the money, we will reinvest them automatically.

The Impact

There are many advantages to buying Better Globe trees. Here are a few of them:

  • Great profits
  • Reducing global warming
  • Being carbon neutral
  • Hindering loss of arable land
    (land that can be used for growing crops)
  • Reducing poverty in Africa
  • Hindering desertification
  • Give children proper education

How can you guarantee a profit?

Better Globe cannot guarantee any profit. We expect a profit, which is based on what we know about the cost of labor and machinery and other forms of overhead and also what we know about the market price of trees and other things that we sell today.

As with any other business activities, you can project expected growth, which is what we have done. What we do not have in our calculation is any price increase in timber from its level today. We have, therefore, been extremely cautious and made moderate (and possibly undervalued) calculations in declaring our intentions to buy back the trees in the 20th year from those who own the trees.

Does Better Globe make money on the poor in Africa?

No, absolutely not! Better Globe earns money on the management of forestry products. We give full-time support to the poor and help them all that we can. They are able to work on a salary, have good health, good employment, and receive an education by working with us. They are also able to obtain financial loans and water and have their children in school. It is a win-win-win concept, and we make absolutely no money on "the poor in Africa".


Does it work?


We have paid all customers and ambassadors since 2006. No one has been left at a loss. We will continue to this in the years to come.

story:
It's Dr. Mark Plotkin's 60th Birthday! Help us raise $60,000 to create the first Trio Indian Shaman’s Encyclopedia. This document* will become a template for tribal peoples throughout the Amazon, providing a tangible way to save oral shamanic wisdom in all of lowland South America.

(*The Encyclopedia will be in the Trio language and only available to the Trio people who can then share the document and their methodologies with fellow tribes. This information will not be made public or translated into any other language, thereby keeping all of the Trio's information safe & private.)

Mark Plotkin’s Amazon Conservation Team partners with indigenous people to protect the rainforest. ACT Advisory Board member Jeff “The Dude” Bridges shares how he learned about the Amazon Conservation Team, as well as the initiatives that continue to make ACT a leader in the conservation movement.

In December of 1982, an American graduate student fleeing a South American civil war paid a bush pilot to drop him on the most remote airstrip in the rainforests of the northeast Amazon. There, Mark Plotkin was met by the Trio Indians, none of whom he knew and whose language he did not speak.

More than three decades later, Dr. Mark Plotkin is considered one of the most innovative and effective conservationists in the world today. And his partnership with the Trio people has endured and flourished, in conjunction with Mark’s organization, the Amazon Conservation Team (ACT).

On the left, Mark (then a graduate student) stands with Kamainja (then a shaman's apprentice) in 1984. On the right, Dr. Mark Plotkin and Kamainja (now a shaman) in 2014.

Together, Mark, ACT and the Trio tribe pioneered an approach to rainforest mapping that spread to 30 other tribes and resulted in the improved management and protection of more than 70 million acres of ancestral rainforest. (See more about this in an interview with Harvard Magazine)

Today, Mark and ACT focus much of their efforts on protecting the last of the uncontacted tribes and their rainforest. (You can learn more about this in Mark’s superb TED Talk)


Background

Of all these accolades and achievements, Mark is best known for partnering with the Trios to create the Shamans and Apprentices Program in which elder shamans pass their botanical healing wisdom to the next generation of healers within the tribe (Watch the Shamans and Apprentices Program in action). ACT provides sponsorships or stipends to support this training so that shamans and apprentices can focus fully on the work. Not only has this resulted in the first book in Trio other than the Bible, but the forest communities and the Amazon Conservation Team have together created four Shamans and Apprentices clinics where traditional medicine is both practiced and taught.

Saving Shamanic Wisdom

Mark Plotkin turns 60 this month, and we want to help him achieve his most important goal: fully documenting the entire spectrum of Trio knowledge of animals and plants into a “Trio Shamanic Encyclopedia and Atlas.” This will entail working closely with elder shamans and tribal youth, equipping them with the training and resources necessary to document this information in their own language and on their own terms. The lasting importance of achieving these goals is the creation of a template that other tribal peoples throughout the Amazon can adapt to their own needs and – in so doing – have a positive impact on saving oral shamanic wisdom in all of lowland South America.

Your donation will provide for the following:

  • Stipends that allow shamans and apprentices to focus fully on their work;
  • Shamans and apprentices’ gatherings for the exchange of healing knowledge; and
  • Notebooks, cameras, and other equipment and training so that apprentices can record shamanic wisdom.

Furthermore, the apprenticeship program provides selected tribal youth with a space where their culture is treated as a source of pride and where values and traditions are encouraged. The skills the apprentices acquire allow them to be leaders in their communities and help them protect their forests and preserve their culture.

We Need Your Help to Make This Possible!

Invite and challenge your family, friends, coworkers, and neighbors to help make this possible by donating a multiple of $60. We need $60,000 to help Mark and his indigenous colleagues create the “Trio Shamanic Encyclopedia and Atlas” and make possible a world in which traditional knowledge and cultures can survive and flourish!

Donate now, find us on Facebook and Twitter, and sign up for our e-newsletter via our website to receive updates about our work.

and Apprentices Program in which elder shamans pass their botanical healing
wisdom to the next generation of healers within the tribe (Watch the Shamans and Apprentices
Program in action). ACT provides sponsorships or stipends to support this
training so that shamans and apprentices can focus fully on the work. Not only
has this resulted in the first book in Trio other than the Bible, but the forest
communities and the Amazon Conservation Team have together created four Shamans
and Apprentices clinics where traditional medicine is both practiced and
taught.


Saving Shamanic Wisdom
Mark Plotkin turns 60 this month, and we want to help him achieve his most
important goal: fully documenting the entire spectrum of Trio knowledge of
animals and plants into a “Trio Shamanic Encyclopedia and Atlas.” This will
entail working closely with elder shamans and tribal youth, equipping them with
the training and resources necessary to document this information in their own
language and on their own terms. The
lasting importance of achieving these goals is the creation of a template that
other tribal peoples throughout the Amazon can adapt to their own needs and –
in so doing – have a positive impact on saving oral shamanic wisdom in all of
lowland South America.
Your donation will provide for
the following:

Stipends
     that allow shamans and apprentices to focus fully on their work;
Shamans
     and apprentices’ gatherings for the exchange of healing knowledge; and
Notebooks, cameras, and
     other equipment and training so that apprentices can record shamanic
     wisdom.

Furthermore, the apprenticeship
program provides selected tribal youth with a space where their culture is
treated as a source of pride and where values and traditions are encouraged.
The skills the apprentices acquire allow them to be leaders in their
communities and help them protect their forests and preserve their culture. 
We Need Your Help to Make This Possible!
Invite and challenge your family,
friends, coworkers, and neighbors to help make this possible by donating a
multiple of $60. We need $60,000 to help Mark and his indigenous colleagues
create the “Trio Shamanic Encyclopedia and Atlas” and make possible a world in
which traditional knowledge and cultures can survive and flourish!
Donate now, find us on Facebook
and Twitter, and sign up for our e-newsletter via our website to receive
updates about our work.

story:
Please Help Fund the Legal Effort!

(To be Updated Shortly -- 7-15-15)

6/12/15 -- Despite years of widespread community opposition in Old Bethpage and Plainview, the Town of Oyster Bay on May 12, 2015 unanimously approved Country Pointe Plainview -- a massive project that will overwhelm the local community and decimate the wildlife and forest on the 143 acre site near the LIE. 

On June 10, 2015, a group of five neighbors on Round Swamp Road appeared in court on their own behalf and under the prodding of the Supreme Court judge hearing the case obtained agreement from the developer not to begin any work, or damage the environment in any way, pending a hearing on July 8, 2015. 

The neighbors -- who are non-lawyers -- filed a massive Article 78 petition detailing and documenting blatant violations of the State Environmental Quality Review Act by the Town which downplayed and distorted the impacts of the project. The lawsuit asks the court to overturn the zoning, site plan, and subdivision plans, and compel a new environmental review.

There is much legal work to be done.

We urgently need funding for a "bond" as required by the Court for a Preliminary Injunction. Without the injunction work may begin even while the lawsuit is pending. We do not know how much will be required, yet, and will not know until the judge decides on it. 

Furthermore we are looking for legal assistance as we move forward and face the full weight of the developer's legal team -- as well as the Town's. 

We need the help now of the hundreds of P/OB residents and others concerned about the environment who testified, wrote letters and emails, and signed petitions against this project over the past few years. PLEASE HELP!!!

THANKS!!

========================================================

This Press Release was issued the day after the case was filed: 

145-acre Development in Plainview-Old Bethpage Challenged  Over Alleged Violations in Environmental Review 

Old Bethpage, June 11, 2015 -- Three Old Bethpage families appeared in State Supreme Court yesterday to file an extensive article 78 lawsuit challenging how the Town of Oyster Bay performed its environmental review of the massive Country Pointe at Plainview development project. 

The judge in the case scheduled a follow-up hearing for July 8, 2015 and obtained consent of all the parties -- represented in court by five attorneys for the Town and the developer -- that no construction or environmental damage would occur before that time.

The lawsuit intends to annul the rezoning, subdivision and site plan, and re-open the environmental review to allow a full accounting of the impacts on wildlife, habitat, and neighboring properties. 

Such a review could result in a re-design better minimizing the environmental impact, as required by the State Environmental Quality Review Act, "SEQRA". 

The site of the proposed project is a 143-acre property sold off by Nassau County in 1998. It currently contains about 60 acres of forest in five separate stands, about 15 soccer fields in two areas, and about a dozen abandoned buildings formerly used by the county as its "Nassau East Office Complex". 

Zoning for the project was approved by the Town of Oyster Bay on May 12, 2015 after years of intense controversy that led Charles Wang to abandon a prior proposed development, and leading to its sale to the present developer Beechwood POB LLC, a Delaware company headquartered in Jericho. 

As approved by the Town, the plans call for completely levelling about 100 acres  across the site to be developed with houses, townhouses, condominiums, some apartments, and stores (Petition, paragraph 29), and leaving the remaining acreage for Town to use, mostly as athletic fields.

While many residents had opposed the project over issues of traffic and density,  -- deluging the Town with petitions, phone calls, letters, and verbal testimony including a hearing in April, 2014, that lasted until 3 AM -- the lawsuit focuses on four areas of environmental review the plaintiffs argue led to fatal flaws in the process.

First, the lawsuit argues that the Town unlawfully "segmented" the environmental review by separating its plans to construct new athletic fields on forest-land it will be given, as well as deferring review of the construction of several new traffic lanes at or nearby the site.

Second, the lawsuit argues that the Town failed to take a required "hard look" at the environmental impact on the roughly 55 of species of wildlife and 47 species of Lepitdoptera on the site -- including foxes, bats and pheasants (petition, paragraphs 72-3). 

The plaintiffs point to a failure to actually count or estimate how many animals are on the site, and allege the Town falsely down-played the value of the dense  forests on the site as habitat for wildlife.

Third, the lawsuit argues that the Town failed to take a required "hard look" at the environmental impact on habitat on the site. The plaintiffs argue the Town engaged in a pattern of using deceptive math and semantics to overstate the amount of wildlife habitat preserved and understate the amount originally present. 

Finally, the lawsuit argues the town failed to take a "hard look" at the visual impact on the neighbors on Round Swamp Road -- of whom all the five plaintiffs are members -- because the analysis of the proposed 125-foot wooded "buffer" intended to shield the development was confused and incomplete.

Among other issues the developer plans to cut a swath through the buffer for a fitness train and fitness stations. 

The State Environmental Quality Review Act ("SEQRA"), which the lawsuit is based on, is the state's bedrock environmental protection law, passed in 1975. 

The law attempts to guarantee that actions by governments and agencies at all levels of the state -- except the State Legislature -- are done in a way that rationally and transparently analyzes and minimizes the negative impacts on the environment. 

The plaintiffs were assisted by East Hills environmental activist Richard Brummel (contact (516) 238-1646, editor Planet-in-Peril.org), who has also been involved in numerous other legal actions in Nassau County directed at protecting the environment from over-development.

"This is a good example of how citizens can and should stand up for their communities and for the limited healthy environment that remains on Long Island, especially in Nassau County. It also documented governments have favored development to the point of undermining environmental law," Mr. Brummel said.

The lawsuit contains 52-pages of text and 48 exhibits including satellite photos and text and graphics from the SEQRA review.

story:
What is THE PROBLEM?

  • Globally, scientists are raising concern about cell phone tower adverse impacts on animals and their habitats.
  • Locally, Verizon plans to locate a cell phone tower in rich habitat used by big horn sheep, bear, deer and other wildlife and refuses to consider less environmentally-sensitive alternative locations.
  • Verizon dismisses Tribal Chairman's request to relocate the tower and protect sacred habitat of "Pah-aht", big horn sheep.
  • Verizon fails to recognize concerned citizens as stakeholders in the cell phone tower project.
  • To date, the county government sides with Verizon. Now concerned citizens are left to stand up to corporate-government alliances.

What is THE SOLUTION?  How will funds be used?

The solution is to change the cell phone tower site!  Less environmentally-sensitive alternative locations for this tower exist. Through unrelenting courage we need to stand up to corporate power and make sure Verizon will consider these alternative sites. As a contributor, you will be helping to set a precedent for global environmentally-conscious cell phone tower placements that pose a minimal threat to animals and their habitats.  You also will be raising public awareness regarding the need for safer cell phone tower technology.  Our success can empower others to take action in their communities.

For three years we have used personal funds to champion our cause. Only now are we turning to the wider community for financial support. Your donations will be used to pay for credentialed professional  environmental reports that will be submitted during a public hearing before county supervisors. These written reports are expensive since they are detailed analyses that can stand up to the studies submitted by Verizon. Scientific experts can ensure that proper, unbiased studies will be put forth at the hearing. 

Where is the habitat and why is it unique?

The habitat is in Mt. Baldy, California, a mountainous area in the Angeles National Forest, and it is unique because it is the only habitat on the mountain that is near three water sources--a natural pond, spring and San Antonio Creek, a primary water source for local big horn sheep. The area is a magnet for wildlife. The denser vegetation around the pond and creek provide wildlife a rich environment for foraging, nesting and camouflaging. The habitat is a complex ecosystem, home to many insects, reptiles, amphibians and abundant wildlife, including numerous bird species, black bear, mule deer, gray foxes, mountain lions, bobcats, coyotes, raccoons and chipmunks, to name a few. USDA-Forest Service and California Fish and Wildlife threatened, sensitive and special concern species reside in the region as well as a Federal and State Endangered species.

What have we been doing to stop construction of the cell phone tower in its environmentally-sensitive location?

We embarked on this journey three years ago, insisting on a biology (California Environmental Quality Act-CEQA) and cultural (Cultural Resource Assessment) study of the site. Using consultants known to have a corporate bias, Verizon's reports were grossly inadequate. Not only did the biology report fail to identify endangered or protected species in the area, the biology field study conducted for the report was done in the winter instead of the spring! This meant that birds that nest or migrate to this habitat in the spring were not identified, nor were reptiles and amphibians due to their winter hibernation.

The cultural report failed to identify the Indian tribe, Gabrieleno Band of Mission Indians Kizh Nation, that has an ancestral connection to the area. More importantly, this proper Indian tribe was never contacted prior to the January public hearing to provide comment on the project site! Also, because of a deficient archeological site survey, the presence of significant cultural resources on the property is still undetermined.

In two public hearings before county planning commissioners, we expressed our concerns about the environmental and cultural sensitivity of Verizon's chosen site and the inadequacy of the biology and cultural reports, but despite our efforts, the commissioners voted to approve the tower location. We have appealed their decision and will now present our concerns before county supervisors.  Due to our appeal, construction of the cell tower facility is on hold.

What are we doing now to stop construction of the cell phone tower in its environmentally-sensitive location?

We are preparing for our upcoming public hearing before county supervisors by securing professional experts, namely in the fields of biology and archeology, to provide written reports regarding the environmental and cultural sensitivity of Verizon's chosen site.

Who are we?

We are concerned citizens. Our grassroots organization, Keep Baldy Wild is a group of residents, hikers and visitors to Mt. Baldy in coalition with businesses, labor, faith-based and community organizations interested in preserving the natural environment of Mt. Baldy.

We are also advocates for citizen participation in government-corporate decisions that affect local communities. We should have input on development in our neighborhoods!  Verizon's unwillingness to consider alternative locations for this tower is unacceptable, especially when thousands of acres are available.  How many times has development occurred in your community without you knowing about it or having a say in the project? Keep Baldy Wild is making progress as a model for other local groups challenging government-corporate decisions. We care about concerned citizens who know what is best for their communities.

We are advocates for safer, environmentally-conscious cell tower installations that have a minimal negative impact on the environment and for safer, biologically-based standards for cell tower radiation (see next section for more information).

What do I need to know about cell towers?

(references listed in Information section below)

Cell towers transmit and receive non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation called radio frequency radiation (RFR). In the journal article, "Electromagnetic Pollution from phone masts. Effects on Wildlife", biologist Alfonso Balmori cites various scientific studies supporting the fact that RFR can adversely impact the nervous, cardiovascular, immune and reproductive systems of animals.1

In Germany, once microwave antennae were installed on a former television/radio tower, cows next to the tower suffered reduced milk yields, emaciation, spontaneous abortions and stillbirths. When the cows were removed to pastures away from the mast, their conditions improved, but deteriorated again when they were brought back to the tower site.3

In a February 2014 letter to the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, the director of the Office of Environmental Policy and Compliance of the United States Department of Interior emphasizes concern about the negative impact of cell tower radiation on the health of migratory birds and other wildlife and recommends placing cell towers in more environmentally benign locations

Why should I care about this issue?

About 5 million cell towers populate the world. In 1985, there were 900 towers in the United States. Today, that figure has risen to 205,000 towers that expand across both urban and rural landscapes. In spite of the vast expansion of cell towers in the past twenty years, inadequate attention has been given to their impact on the environment, particularly with respect to the biological effect of cell tower radio frequency radiation (RFR) on wildlife, insects and plants. Until a biologically safe RFR standard for cell towers is established, it is important for communities to uphold the principle of "prudent avoidance" by insisting that towers are placed at a distance from humans, wildlife and environmentally rich areas.

How can I obtain more information?

For more information/questions about our campaign, please contact us via email: info@keepbaldywild.com or visit our website. Check for updates on our campaign's progress on our Indiegogo site. Please see the following references/links for educational material on cell towers and radio frequency radiation:

  1. A. Balmori. Electromagnetic pollution from phone masts. Effects on wildlife. Pathophysiology 16 (2009) 191.
  2. G.J. Hyland. Physics and biology of mobile telephony. Lancet 356 (2000) 1833.
  3. W. Loscher, G. Kas. Conspicuous behavioural abnormalities in a dairy cow herd near a TV and radio transmitting antenna. Pract. Vet. Surg. 79 (1998) 437.
  4. A. Balmori. Electrosmog and Species Conservation. Science of the Total Environment 496 (2014) 314.
  5. Letter from Office of Environmental Policy and Compliance concerning cell phone towers and migratory birds (February 2014).
  6. Need for a biologically-based electromagnetic radiation exposure standard:
    • The BioInitiative Report
    • 2014 BioInitiative Update
  7. Re-classification of radio frequency radiation as a probable carcinogen:
    • Official Press Release (May 2011)
    • Dr. Anthony Miller speaks before Toronto Council
  8. Electromagnetic Radiation Safety: blog authored by Dr. Joel M. Moskowitz, School of Public Health, UC Berkeley.

What are our risks/challenges?

Standing up to the telecom giant, Verizon, is not easy.  Many hours of research and outreach have been spent on this cutting-edge effort.  No matter how steep the climb, through your support, we will push forward.  Together, by setting a precedent for the safer placement of cell phone towers and for safer cell phone tower technology, we can protect the health of the planet. Help us turn the page on this critical environmental issue.

How else can I help?  Can we help you?

Tell your friends and use the Indiegogo share tools to direct them to our Indiegogo/Environment campaign! Let us know if we can help support YOU with your campaign to stop intrusive, improper development in your neighborhood or in environmentally-sensitive habitat. We have helpful resources and invaluable guidance to share.

What do the perks look like?

Choose a tax-deductible perk!  All contributions are tax-deductible.

Keep Baldy Wild Bumper Sticker

Musical CD Album "Things Have Changed" by Squeakin' Wheels

story:
Short Summary

Wherever we live, we are connected by the flow of water. This web of life is called a watershed. *

Civic Center Watershed Restoration (CCWR) is a project to improve the water quality of the Marin Civic Center lagoon which is part of the Gallinas Watershed in North San Rafael, CA.

We did it! On October 16, 2015 we installed two demonstration floating island biofilters at the Civic Center lagoon. The planting and launch activity was part of the annual Bioneers Conference and this hands-on activity for the entire community was attended by over 100 volunteers. We even got front page coverage in the Marin IJ newspaper.

If you live in the Bay Area or you like promoting natural ways to protect and enhance our watersheds, then this project is for you.

Watch our 2 minute video (by Aurora Mahassine and Cynthia Abbott):

What We Need & What You Get

CCWR is a project of the Gallinas Watershed Council of North San Rafael. We are supported by a coalition of business, foundations, and volunteers intent on improving the health of the Civic Center Lagoon and Las Gallinas Creek.

Our focus is on education and community engagement to foster stewardship of our natural commons. We have researched and gathered feedback and collected project ideas for creek and lagoon restoration activities.

The floating island bio-filter is one of the bio-technologies that CCWR researched and then proposed to Marin County for the Civic Center lagoon. With plantings on the surface and roots in the water, they provide natural water filtration and wildlife habitat. Once installed, floating islands require little maintenance.

This green technology was pioneered by John Todd. Watch his presentation at the Bioneers Conference to learn about floating island biofilters:


Our project has already gathered funds from grants and sponsors, and now we are fundraising to pay for all the items we need:
  • Floating island biofilters
  • Native Plants
  • Informational Signage
  • Informational literature

We will need another $5000 to launch our floating islands. Please support us in any way you can. We even have some perks if you're interested!

The Impact

The Marin County Civic Center is a state and national Historic Site and a UNESCO-nominated World Heritage Site. As conceived by Frank Lloyd Wright, the Civic Center Lagoon and its surrounding parklands are an area for recreation, notable in that they interconnect manicured landscapes with the natural world. The lagoon connects directly to the South Fork of Gallinas Creek and the San Pablo Bay marshlands, habitat for endangered species such as the Salt Marsh Harvest Mouse and California Ridgeway’s Rail (formerly California Clapper Rail).

The Marin Civic Center, which includes the county administrative offices, county fair grounds, and a performing arts and convention center, is going through a substantial transformation. A SMART train station, Civic Center Drive Improvements Project and proposed Farmers Market complex are all clustered near the site of the lagoon and the South Fork of Gallinas Creek.

Floating island biofilters have been successfully used around the world. Closer to home there have been launched by similar community funded-coalitions in Walnut Creek and Marysville, CA.

Learn about a similar floating island biofilter project at Heather Farm in Walnut Creek:


Challenges

While floating island have been successful around the world, they are new to Marin County. Our project at the Civic Center is attracting lots of attention. We hope it will result in more floating island projects as well as additional measures to help the Gallinas Watershed.

  • We only have a few days to raise funds and pay for our floating island.
  • We have a great team of volunteers that includes the Santa Venetia Neighborhood Association and the Marin School of Environmental Leadership.

Ways You Can Help

Your help now will demonstrate that a model of local business, foundations, and community groups can join with government to foster community stewardship of a Marin County watershed.

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our project.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Join us in thanking our supporters.
  • Contact us if you would like to help in any other way

And that's all there is to it.

Thanks to all our Supporters

Autodesk
Bioneers Conference
Bioneers Indigenous Youth Council
Cultural Conservancy
Embassy Suites Hotel San Rafael
Environmental Forum of Marin
Frank Lloyd Wright Civic Center Conservancy
Floating Islands West
Kahl Consultants
Kamman Hydrology (KHE)
Marin County Supervisor Damon Connolly
MarinLink
Marin School of Environmental Leadership (MSEL)
Santa Venetia Neighborhood Association
Watershed Alliance of Marin

*What is a Watershed?

A watershed is not a shed that stores water, but an area of land that “catches” water, or a “catchment.” It is defined by topography—the shape of the land—rather than by political boundaries or property lines. Water flows from higher parts of the landscape, such as ridges, towards lower areas, such as valleys or ravines. Runoff often forms a river or creek that makes its way toward a lake, bay or ocean.

A watershed is a place where all beings are connected through the life-giving flow of water. As water moves over and through the landscape, it carries soil and rock to form new habitats, brings sustenance to plants, and gives nourishment to wildlife and human communities.

Just as creeks can be part of larger river systems, smaller watersheds are part of larger watersheds. So, too, are humans, wildlife, and elements of earth held within this branching web of life.

story:
Short Summary

This is a potential world-changing experiment that could help billions of people in need of clean water.  Thank you so much for taking the time to watch our video, we hope you will be part of this important mission.  Check out http://www.novatx.com to learn more about Dr. Paul Pierce and his work.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking funding to generate a purely unbiased scientific experiment to prove or disprove water's ability to hold memory.  We will answer the question of whether or not human consciousness and intention can impact the state of water molecules.  This claim has been made by Dr. Masaru Emoto and we aim to scientifically end the debate on whether or not his findings are true.  

The Impact

If this experiment finds that water does in fact hold memory, it will have an enormous impact on the world concerning our fundamental relationship to water. These findings can open the door for countless new technologies that would be accessible for people around the world in need of clean water.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this video with your friends, and keep your mind open.  Thank you so much for taking the time to watch our video, we hope to fulfill our promise to end the debate on this important issue.
