story:
Short Summary

Harvest Farms is a small scale organic farm in Bilpin, NSW dedicated to restorative agriculture. Our farm includes a thriving 2 acre market garden and now we are attempting to bring back to life a 700 tree apple orchard which was abandoned 8 years ago.

To As part of this restoration we will be using miniature goats to improve soil quality, control invasive weeds, and manage grass growth. We are restoring this orchard with a focus on producing pesticide-free apples for local consumers and preserving a living archive of apple varieties disappearing from our food culture.

The Impact

The method of orchard restoration we will be using allows control of many pests and weeds without chemical applications. Silvopasture is a method of grazing animals to control invasive weeds within wooded areas which can compete with desired plants for nutrients, sunlight, and water. Grazing animals the right way can also greatly improve soil quality without the use of chemical fertilizers or other unsustainable inputs. We intend to increase the value of our apples by growing them in in this manner. We will make the project financially sustainable by selling this amazing new variety of miniature dairy goats.

What We Need & What You Get

We need Nigerian Dwarf Goats. This miniature dairy goat can be grazed in small spaces as well as provide additional value products such as milk and cheese. We need to purchase a high % Nigerian Dwarf pedigree buck in order to start breeding these goats reliably. Many hobby farmers would benefit from having a small backyard herd to provide fresh, healthy milk for their families and communities and these miniature goats require much less space than traditional dairy animals.

We have chosen Nigerian Dwarf Goats for multiple reasons in addition to the ones stated above. They have the richest goat milk of any breed (with a butterfat content of 6-10%) as well as produce more milk per kilo of feed consumed than large dairy goat breeds. This small animal can also graze under our dwarf root stock apple trees without damaging fruit production which is key to orchard restoration. 

Contributing to this farm enterprise puts you in the unique position of helping a local farmer dedicated to restorative farming. By contributing you will become part of this farm by having access to apples from trees you have helped restore, being able to visit goats you "adopted,"and touring the farm. These are all ways you will get to be a farmer without spending the hours in the dirt and sun required to actually run a farm!

    Risks & Challenges

    The Nigerian Dwarf Goat breed has recently been introduced to Australia and, due to border bio-security control, costs of animals of this breed are still quite high. In choosing Nigerian Dwarf Goats we are hoping to help increase the pool of farmers working to develop the breed here in Australia. This poses a challenge in having the startup funds to purchase a small herd of animals to begin a breeding program, that's where you come in! You will be in on the grass roots level of introducing this fabulous dairy goat to more of Australia as our farm begins to thrive. 

    We also need to be aware and prepared for any health or safety risks to the animals; including predators, weather, and illnesses. We need to buy proper fencing, housing, feed/mineral supplements, etc. and make connections with a local veterinarian before we are ready to bring animals onto our farm. We have been researching our options and talking to local farmers and feel confident that we will be able to do this as soon as we have sufficient funding.  

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Harvest Farms is more than just a project, it's a functioning farm that would greatly benefit from you getting the word out about what we do! Check out www.harvestfarms.com.au for more info as well as our Facebook and Instagram and share away! 

    To get more involved you can sign up to the CSA boxes, come to farm dinners, visit us at farmers markets, and visit the farm. All of these things contribute to the whole farm system we are working to grow!

story:
UPDATE 02/28/2021: We officially released MEET BOB on January 26th, 2021 and books are now available.

-------------

Who is Bob?

Through my first book "MEET BOB", I provide an exclusive look into the colourful life of Bob. Bob enjoys breakfasts of caviar, dips in his own saltwater pool, and biweekly foot massages on the beach. A charmed life, perhaps, but he deserves it: Bob spends much of his time interacting with school children on his home island Curaçao.  He is an emissary for conservation.

Bob, you see, is a flamingo.

 

Veterinarian Odette Doest rescued Bob in 2016, after he had slammed into a hotel window. While rehabilitating the bird at her nonprofit wildlife sanctuary, Fundashon Dier en Onderwijs Cariben (Foundation for Animals and Education in the Caribbean), Odette discovered that not only did the flamingo have a concussion and an injured left wing, but, he had previously been domesticated.  Bob was too relaxed around people; he also suffered from bumblefoot, a chronic foot disease common in captive birds, which would impair his ability to catch food in the wild.

 

Because of his injuries, Odette decided to keep Bob as an educational animal at her sanctuary. When she started taking him on her foundation’s weekly visits to schools and community gathering spots on the Dutch Caribbean isle, the flamingo became an instant celebrity.  Bob's fame now helps Odette tell a larger story:  the duo work together to make people more aware of environmental issues in the Caribbean.

 

Why this book?

For me, the story of Bob is very personal.  

MEET BOB is not ‘just a book.’   It’s a fundraising campaign for conservation, and you get the book for free. 

My father was born on Curaçao, a relatively small island North of Venezuela.  He moved to The Netherlands when he was a little boy, where I was born and raised. It took me 27 years before I visited my father’s birthplace. I don’t know exactly why... ⠀

 During my late teens I developed a close relationship with my cousin Odette.  She was studying at the Faculty of Veterinary Practices in Utrecht and I was interested in photography.  She would visit our home with stories and pictures of wildlife in the Peruvian jungle.  When I finally visited her during the summer of 2006, I remember noticing how much we have in common.  While she would visit us visit every year in NL, it took me another 10 years before I would visit her again. Again, I don't know why...

When I visited Curacao again in 2016,  Odette had just rescued a flamingo.  He couldn’t be released back to the wild; he was a relaxed, chill being, and we named him Bob.  On the second day of my visit, as the bedside clock was changing to 7:00 am, Bob’s head peaked through the door to my room — it was in the early hours of that morning, our photographic journey began.  Little did we both know how many lives would positively be affected by our actions.

 

On the final day of my last visit, I joined Bob for a swim in the crystal clear waters surrounding the island. As I swam back to beach to call it a day and head to the airport, I looked back at the odd couple bobbing at sea. They live a remarkable life together, although, to them it’s just their daily life. To me, their story is an intimate love story about how two individuals, that depend on each other, initiate positive change by educating future generations. And, even though I’d rather see Bob return to the wild, it’s good to know that together with Odette he’s able to make a real difference. It's been a year now since I've visited them and I miss them dearly. This time, I do know why ❤️. 

The story of Bob and Odette has been well received in the media through a large variety of international magazine publications.  Bob’s story was celebrated in the 2019 World Press Photo contest, Wildlife Photographer of the Year, Pictures of the Year International and the Sony World Photography Awards. In 2020, Bob proudly graced the pages of National Geographic Magazine.   

People from all over the world have reached out to us on how much they appreciate Odette's work and how she is a role model for many. While all the acknowledgements have been heart warming, I have personally wanted to do something more for Odette, for Bob, and for wildlife conservation in the Caribbean.  As the island of Curaçao holds the roots to my heritage, MEET BOB is my tribute to my own history,  a celebration of the color in my life and my small contribution to the island's future. 

Odette’s wildlife rescue work is completely self-funded through her income as a veterinarian. When an injured wild animal is brought into FDOC, Odette pays for all of their care out of her own pocket.  Therefore, I have decided that all revenues of this book will be donated to the conservation and education work of FDOC, so that we can all help support the important conservation work of FDOC.  

This book is an opportunity for me to help someone who tries to make this world a better place. This book celebrates Bob and Odette. Their story is a reminder that individual actions, driven by love and empathy, can have an enormous positive impact on the world around us. Never would I have thought about doing a story about a family member, but it's proves this power lives in all of us; compassion and empathy as the starting point of positive change. Something this world needs, more than ever. 

This book is MY way of giving back.

MEET BOB possible cover mock-up 

 

Supporting this book and FDOC

Your support will make this publication a reality and will help FDOC to continue their rescue, rehabilitation and education plan.  

NOTEWORTHY BOOK SPECS:

  • Portrait Format - 234x325x14mm
  • 88 pages
  • Approximately 80 images
  • 5-color printing + 1 PMS color to create the beautiful vibrant color palette in print
  • Hard cover, sewn binding
  • Printed on sustainably sourced paper
  • Estimated arrival December 2020
  • Special limited handbound edition will be available


When you purchase your copy of MEET BOB or one of our other perks, you’ll be helping us to reach our crowdfunding goal of €25.000 EUR. Our funding tiers start with the support of FDOC and end with a limited edition copy of MEET BOB including three hand signed fine art prints.

Our costs include: 

  • Printing! When we meet our goal we'll be printing  3.000 copies of this hard cover first edition.
  • Book packaging and shipping
  • Distribution
  • Advertising and PR
  • Travel costs and overhead for conferences to present the book globally in 2021.
  • The people working on this book: the time of the co-editors, the designer, the colour editor, the project manager.
  • Biweekly foot massages on the beach to keep Flamingo Bob satisfied.

 

MEET BOB will be published by LIMOSA. As a result, any profit from MEET BOB will go directly into funding the work of FDOC. 

 

The Impact

Meet Bob is an intimate love story about compassion and empathy. More specifically about how two individuals, that depend on each other, initiate positive change by educating future generations. 

I hope you'll order your copy of MEET BOB, and share this campaign. In doing so, you will be helping us produce, print, and distribute this hardcover first edition of MEET BOB. This is your chance to help the rescue and rehabilitation of many wild animals in the Caribbean while at the same time educate both children and adults about the importance of protecting the Caribbean wildlife. Let's help Bob to make this world a better place.

Thank you in advance!

Your's sincerely,

Jasper Doest

P.S. We are working very hard to ship your order in time. However, COVID19 currently has a big impact on postal services world wide. Thank you for understanding and your support.

 

About the photographer

Dutch photographer Jasper Doest creates visual stories that explore the relationship between humankind and nature. Having majored in ecology, Doest knows human life depends on everything our planet has to offer, yet he recognizes the unsustainable nature of the current human patterns of consumption. As a true believer in the power of photography to initiate change, Doest is an International League of Conservation Photographers senior fellow and a World Wildlife Fund ambassador. He is also a contributing photographer for National Geographic magazine and has received awards from World Press Photo and Wildlife Photographer of the Year.
story_txt:
UPDATE 02/28/2021: We officially released MEET BOB on January 26th, 2021 and books are now available.
-------------
Who is Bob?
Through my first book "MEET BOB", I provide an exclusive look into the colourful life of Bob. Bob enjoys breakfasts of caviar, dips in his own saltwater pool, and biweekly foot massages on the beach. A charmed life, perhaps, but he deserves it: Bob spends much of his time interacting with school children on his home island Curaçao.  He is an emissary for conservation.
Bob, you see, is a flamingo.

 
Veterinarian Odette Doest rescued Bob in 2016, after he had slammed into a hotel window. While rehabilitating the bird at her nonprofit wildlife sanctuary, Fundashon Dier en Onderwijs Cariben (Foundation for Animals and Education in the Caribbean), Odette discovered that not only did the flamingo have a concussion and an injured left wing, but, he had previously been domesticated.  Bob was too relaxed around people; he also suffered from bumblefoot, a chronic foot disease common in captive birds, which would impair his ability to catch food in the wild.
 

Because of his injuries, Odette decided to keep Bob as an educational animal at her sanctuary. When she started taking him on her foundation’s weekly visits to schools and community gathering spots on the Dutch Caribbean isle, the flamingo became an instant celebrity.  Bob's fame now helps Odette tell a larger story:  the duo work together to make people more aware of environmental issues in the Caribbean.
 
Why this book?
For me, the story of Bob is very personal.  
MEET BOB is not ‘just a book.’   It’s a fundraising campaign for conservation, and you get the book for free. 
My father was born on Curaçao, a relatively small island North of Venezuela.  He moved to The Netherlands when he was a little boy, where I was born and raised. It took me 27 years before I visited my father’s birthplace. I don’t know exactly why... ⠀
 During my late teens I developed a close relationship with my cousin Odette.  She was studying at the Faculty of Veterinary Practices in Utrecht and I was interested in photography.  She would visit our home with stories and pictures of wildlife in the Peruvian jungle.  When I finally visited her during the summer of 2006, I remember noticing how much we have in common.  While she would visit us visit every year in NL, it took me another 10 years before I would visit her again. Again, I don't know why...
When I visited Curacao again in 2016,  Odette had just rescued a flamingo.  He couldn’t be released back to the wild; he was a relaxed, chill being, and we named him Bob.  On the second day of my visit, as the bedside clock was changing to 7:00 am, Bob’s head peaked through the door to my room — it was in the early hours of that morning, our photographic journey began.  Little did we both know how many lives would positively be affected by our actions.
 
On the final day of my last visit, I joined Bob for a swim in the crystal clear waters surrounding the island. As I swam back to beach to call it a day and head to the airport, I looked back at the odd couple bobbing at sea. They live a remarkable life together, although, to them it’s just their daily life. To me, their story is an intimate love story about how two individuals, that depend on each other, initiate positive change by educating future generations. And, even though I’d rather see Bob return to the wild, it’s good to know that together with Odette he’s able to make a real difference. It's been a year now since I've visited them and I miss them dearly. This time, I do know why ❤️. 
The story of Bob and Odette has been well received in the media through a large variety of international magazine publications.  Bob’s story was celebrated in the 2019 World Press Photo contest, Wildlife Photographer of the Year, Pictures of the Year International and the Sony World Photography Awards. In 2020, Bob proudly graced the pages of National Geographic Magazine.   
People from all over the world have reached out to us on how much they appreciate Odette's work and how she is a role model for many. While all the acknowledgements have been heart warming, I have personally wanted to do something more for Odette, for Bob, and for wildlife conservation in the Caribbean.  As the island of Curaçao holds the roots to my heritage, MEET BOB is my tribute to my own history,  a celebration of the color in my life and my small contribution to the island's future. 

Odette’s wildlife rescue work is completely self-funded through her income as a veterinarian. When an injured wild animal is brought into FDOC, Odette pays for all of their care out of her own pocket.  Therefore, I have decided that all revenues of this book will be donated to the conservation and education work of FDOC, so that we can all help support the important conservation work of FDOC.  
This book is an opportunity for me to help someone who tries to make this world a better place. This book celebrates Bob and Odette. Their story is a reminder that individual actions, driven by love and empathy, can have an enormous positive impact on the world around us. Never would I have thought about doing a story about a family member, but it's proves this power lives in all of us; compassion and empathy as the starting point of positive change. Something this world needs, more than ever. 
This book is MY way of giving back.

MEET BOB possible cover mock-up 
 
Supporting this book and FDOC
Your support will make this publication a reality and will help FDOC to continue their rescue, rehabilitation and education plan.  NOTEWORTHY BOOK SPECS:

Jasper Doest

story:
www.BloomingBiodiversity.org

Who Are We?

The Solutionaries are a diverse team of social-environmental activists, dedicated to co-creating a resilient and regenerative lifestyle for ourselves, our local and global community, our natural world, and future generations. We are co-organizing the Blooming Biodiversity Tour which begins this September on the North American West Coast. Our tour will include empowering days of action with interactive workshops for social and environmental evolution including: permaculture and biodynamic farming, gardening, live music, yoga, healing, expressive and visionary arts and ecstatic dance integrated into communities and Ecovillages.



What Are We Doing?

In every location, we will be gathering communities for the integration of permaculture principles and values, holistic education and transformational festival culture, in action. We are inviting anyone who feels enthusiastically empowered to bring their skill-sets and passion to the co-creation of this tour. Through these activating permaculture experiences, participants will experience the beauty of living in harmony with nature and supporting each other in community.To make this all happen, we will need your help from the grassroots up! 

The Purpose: 

  • To help shift the paradigm from a corporate ruled industrial complex to an intentional, community-created, thriving co-existence.

  • To nurture the blooming of regenerative biodiversity everywhere we go.

  • To envision and strategize ways to transcend existing patterns o f global inequality.

  • To empower community to restore the commons and a culturally rich lifestyle.

  • To generate a self-sustaining livelihood with community initiated food gardens and organic innovative design.

  • To initiate conversations and catalyze the process of soil and ecosystem restoration, water purification and green energy system installation (ie: solar/wind power).

  • To inspire a new world vision for communities to live in a way that is healthy for the planet and humanity.

  • To act locally and connect globally.

  • To foster cross-cultural and intergenerational collaboration.

  • To share healing, visionary and expressive art, music and dance. Because if it’s not fun it’s not sustainable.

  • To put solutions into action, and bring forth our greatest potential through collaborative symbiosis. 



You can choose where your greatly appreciated money goes, through selecting which aspects you are most excited about on our campaign website survey.

Choose here: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/2XCPKYQ

These Projects Include: 

Our core principles are earth care, people care, and fair share. We are dedicated to cultivating a regenerative, thriving and abundant world that is equitable and accessible for all. We have found recent success in our pre-tour summer events that we have organized in order to both get the word out and develop the necessary experience to launch a full three-month tour.

Innovate Solutions

       Our tour is one aspect of the larger movement towards cultivating a thriving, just, sustainable, regenerative, and equitable world. Joanna Macy speaks about the three spheres of influence, which are holding actions (anything that slows down the industrial growth complex), solution focused actions (being the change we want to see), and inner transformation. All three spheres support one another and are necessary for creating positive change. Our tour combines all three spheres.

      The Blooming Biodiversity Permaculture Tour provides innovative experiences for both long-time permaculture activists and those who have never set foot in a garden. It creates an access point and a bridge to bring people together who may have varying interests. We will be working in each community to create lasting impact by empowering local community members to maintain the momentum that our events generate after we leave. We will be teaching participants how to organize their own similar events, so that the permaculture work and community building experiences can continue indefinitely. 

 Our tour will help benefit those in need of resilient lifestyles, those who do not have enough healthy food to eat, and those who are disconnected from their local communities.

Positive Impact

   We will be training all participants to create their own permaculture activations in their local communities, so the positive transformation can continue after we go. We project that our participants will be inspired to integrate permaculture principles, community connection, and regenerative practices into their lifestyles. We have already seen many participants modifying their life paths after attending our events. We have been seeing and will see permaculture projects that would normally take a month to finish, be completed within a day of work. Over a three-year period, we project to see community members creating their own permaculture events and permaculture tours. We project to see thriving urban and rural food forests and edible gardens, grey-water and water catchment systems that utilize all rainfall and excess water, and more connected communities, all along the North American West Coast and beyond. 


Projected Costs

We can only realize this dream with the support of our community. To tour in an eco-friendly manner, create regenerative infrastructure, and assist the creation of resilient communities everywhere we go, requires financial support through your donations to our indieGogo campaign.
We are so grateful for your contributions to help us actualize this tour and for taking action with us to create a reality where we can all thrive. 

From the bottom of our hearts, and our gardens, thank you. 

www.BloomingBiodiversity.org

Please Share This Link: igg.me/at/bloomingbiodiversity

To help shift the paradigm from a corporate ruled industrial complex to an intentional, community-created, thriving co-existence.

You can choose where your greatly appreciated money goes, through selecting which aspects you are most excited about on our campaign website survey.
Choose here: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/2XCPKYQ
These Projects Include: 



Raised urban garden beds for vegetables


Food forest fruit trees


Swales, burms, marshes, and collection ponds for greywater systems


Renewable energy infrastructure: solar/wind/hydro


Outdoor education


Ecovillage community housing and gardens for houseless and underserved


Native medicinal herb spirals


Compost, Manure, EMOI, Biochar


Natural building: Cob, Stick and Slip, Straw Bale, Adobe, Earthship, Bamboo


Intersection street mural


Apothocary: wildcrafted herbs


Seedlings for greenhouses


Composting toliets


Expressive arts therapy (art, music,dance, theater, poetry) for social and enviro justice


Mandala and keyhole polyculture gardens


Drought resistant landscaping


Native Habitat Restoration


Beach Clean Ups


Mycology and Microremediation


Healing Arts: yoga/meditation/mindfulness/chigong/reiki/soundhealing


Environmental hands on education for underserved youth



Our Principles:

Our core principles are earth care, people care, and fair share. We are dedicated to cultivating a regenerative, thriving and abundant world that is equitable and accessible for all. We have found recent success in our pre-tour summer events that we have organized in order to both get the word out and develop the necessary experience to launch a full three-month tour.Innovate Solutions

       Our tour is one aspect of the larger movement towards cultivating a thriving, just, sustainable, regenerative, and equitable world. Joanna Macy speaks about the three spheres of influence, which are holding actions (anything that slows down the industrial growth complex), solution focused actions (being the change we want to see), and inner transformation. All three spheres support one another and are necessary for creating positive change. Our tour combines all three spheres.

It creates an access point and a bridge to bring people together who may have varying interests. We will be teaching participants how to organize their own similar events, so that the permaculture work and community building experiences can continue indefinitely. 


 Our tour will help benefit those in need of resilient lifestyles, those who do not have enough healthy food to eat, and those who are disconnected from their local communities.



Positive Impact
   We will be training all participants to create their own permaculture activations in their local communities, so the positive transformation can continue after we go. We project that our participants will be inspired to integrate permaculture principles, community connection, and regenerative practices into their lifestyles. We have already seen many participants modifying their life paths after attending our events. We have been seeing and will see permaculture projects that would normally take a month to finish, be completed within a day of work. Over a three-year period, we project to see community members creating their own permaculture events and permaculture tours. We project to see thriving urban and rural food forests and edible gardens, grey-water and water catchment systems that utilize all rainfall and excess water, and more connected communities, all along the North American West Coast and beyond. 

Projected Costs



Food Costs: $9,000Healthy nutritious food is necessary for taking positive transformative action. 
Shovels and Hand Tools $333 and Work Gloves $65These are the bare necessities of effective permaculture work. Every permaculture activist need these essentials. We want to be ready to provide for both our team and local participants. 

Starter Trees for Food Forests $1,000, Starter Plants for Edible Gardens $400, and Organic Seed Packs, $250   To plant edible gardens and food forests, we need starter plants and seeds. We plan to plant many pollinator habitats to encourage bees, hummingbirds, and other pollinators to sweep the West Coast in greater abundance. We plan to plant many edible gardens and food forests to make organic local food more accessible to communities.
Tubes for Greywater Systems  $525One of the greatest issues facing the West Coast today is our lack of water. By utilizing our excess water to feed our plants, we are taking a huge step in a regenerative direction. 
Clay and Straw for Natural Building Projects (Cob Benches, Cob Ovens, Cob and Straw Bale Outdoor Classrooms) $1,000Natural building is a fun and powerful method of getting in touch with the earth while building long lasting sustainable infrastructure that can be used for many purposes. Building an outdoor educational classroom out of cob will engage local students, create memorable experiences, and plant a setting for outdoor education classes. Cob benches in neighborhoods will create environments for neighbors and passersby to sit and connect with one another, enjoy time in a community garden, and build community. 
Bags of Mulch  $560Every garden needs to be mulched. Mulching is a fun and engaging activity that helps utilize water optimally, keeps out weeds, and adds beauty to the garden. 

Total: $11,111



We can only realize this dream with the support of our community. To tour in an eco-friendly manner, create regenerative infrastructure, and assist the creation of resilient communities everywhere we go, requires financial support through your donations to our indieGogo campaign.
We are so grateful for your contributions to help us actualize this tour and for taking action with us to create a reality where we can all thrive. 



From the bottom of our hearts, and our gardens, thank you. 


www.BloomingBiodiversity.orgPlease Share This Link: igg.me/at/bloomingbiodiversity

story:
Arizona Doug DoucheBAG may hate the environment, but that doesn't mean YOU have to! He may have banned plastic bag bans, he may be in bed with the Koch Brothers, he may even be plotting a tree ban as we speak so we can't hug them... But it's Earth Day, and everyone can use (and reuse) a DoucheBAG.

So just in time for Earth Day, Rogue Green with the artistic assistance of illustrator extraordinaire Claire Thomas bring you the "I hate the environment" Doug DoucheBAG bag.

Why is such a reusable bag necessary?

Well, because Arizona Governor Doug Douchey recently signed SB1241 which prohibits cities, counties and towns from enacting any kind of plastic bag or styrofoam ban or ordinance. (It prohibits cities from enacting energy benchmarking ordinances too which could have saved businesses, schools and the government MILLIONS of dollars, but we have a feeling the Gov. is more concerned with what his petroleum industry buddies think of him.) Basically, Gov. Doug hates the environment. And we want to see these bags everywhere across our fine state and beyond. 

Yes, even though more than 5000 people emailed him, called him, signed petitions and the story was picked up locally as well as in the New York Times, Slate and DAILY KOS, our fine Governor gave a big F YOU to the environment. So, we feel it's only right that something good come out of it on Earth Day as an F you back to him.

Why are plastic bags bad?

Arizona Economic Impacts of Plastic Bags

•Phoenix must spend $1 million (or more) annually due to plastic bags jamming the recycling equipment at the City of Phoenix’s MRF. 

•Approximately $66,700 is spent annually to address litter at Cinder Lake Landfill in Flagstaff. Landfill staff estimate that 80% of all wind-blown litter that gets past litter fences consists of plastic bags. In FY 2013, 3,785 bags of wind-blown litter were collected. This cost the City $17.62 per wind-blown litter bag.

•Flagstaff spends $62,400 annually due to shutting down recycling equipment for up to two hours a day to remove plastic bags at City of Flagstaff’s MRF. 

•Some landfills spend more than $200,000 a year just to deal with stray plastic bags, not to mention recycling equipment breakdowns and repair costs.

•Recommunity Recycling, which services the City of Tempe, estimates that single-use plastic bags cost the city $150,000 annually in direct labor costs (cleaning and repairing machinery, capturing bags), plus $60,000 in lost revenue due to missing good clean recyclables while they are chasing bags.

•Sedona Recycles is a small rural recycling center with free drop off sites in Sedona and the Verde Valley. Plastic bags pose a major problem for operation at a cost of $19,000 per year in disposal and removal.  An extra conveyor belt to carry the bags off the line also had to be installed at a cost of $2,000.  

Environmental Impacts of Plastic Bags

·The total cost of litter collection, disposal and enforcement in the U.S. is estimated to be at least $11.5 billion annually. Businesses bear the burden of this cost, spending $9.1 billion annually and representing 79.5% of the total cost of litter abatement.

·The Guinness Book of World Records named the plastic bag as the most ubiquitous consumer product of 2009, produced on the worldwide scale by the trillions. Approximately 1 million bags are used every minute.

·In the United States alone, an estimated 12 million barrels of oil is used annually to make plastic bags that Americans consume, which works out to over 100 billion (bags) per year.

·Impact of manufacturing 9 plastic bags is greater than that of driving a car 6/10 of a mile. This means that the annual consumption of plastic bags in the US (100 billion) is the equivalent of driving a car 6.67 billion miles… or more than 35 round trips from the Earth to the Sun.

·Each ton of recycled bags saves the energy equivalent of 11 barrels of oil.

·EPA estimates only 12% of plastic bags are being recycled.

·In 2011 alone we placed 200 million plastic bags into landfills.

·Once plastic has photodegraded to minute pieces in our oceans (often called a plastic soup), these small pieces of plastic are often mistaken by fish, birds or marine mammals and reptiles as food. Plastic particles provide no nutrients. As animals continue to feed on plastic, they take in more and more plastic material until they slowly starve to death.

·Plastic is found floating in all the world’s oceans, everywhere from polar region to the equator.

·Some parts of the ocean are like a plastic soup, where there are six pounds of plastic for every pound of plankton. Approx. 60-80% of marine debris is composed of plastics Approx. 80% of marine debris is from land-based sources.

·Over 100,000 marine mammals die each year from ingestion or entanglement in plastics and over 1 million sea birds.

·60-80% of marine debris is composed of plastics.

How can you help?

  • Our goal is to get as many of these bags made as possible, so every little bit will help. If you can't financially contribute, please share this campaign with all of your friends and family and through social media channels.
  • Please remember to VOTE in the next election cycle.
  • We will be selling the Doug DoucheBAGS to simply cover our costs. 100% of proceeds raised after our costs are met will be donated to the Sierra Club Grand Canyon Chapter to help assist them with the great work they're doing.

Happy Earth Day!

This cost the City $17.62 per wind-blown litter bag.
•Flagstaff spends $62,400 annually due to shutting down recycling equipment for up to two hours a day to remove plastic bags at City of Flagstaff’s MRF. 
•Some landfills spend more than $200,000 a year just to deal with stray plastic bags, not to mention recycling equipment breakdowns and repair costs.
•Recommunity Recycling, which services the City of Tempe, estimates that single-use plastic bags cost the city $150,000 annually in direct labor costs (cleaning and repairing machinery, capturing bags), plus $60,000 in lost revenue due to missing good clean recyclables while they are chasing bags.
•Sedona Recycles is a small rural recycling center with free drop off sites in Sedona and the Verde Valley. Plastic bags pose a major problem for operation at a cost of $19,000 per year in disposal and removal.  An extra conveyor belt to carry the bags off the line also had to be installed at a cost of $2,000.  
Environmental Impacts of Plastic Bags

·The total cost of litter collection, disposal and enforcement in the U.S. is estimated to be at least $11.5 billion annually. Businesses bear the burden of this cost, spending $9.1 billion annually and representing 79.5% of the total cost of litter abatement.
·The Guinness Book of World Records named the plastic bag as the most ubiquitous consumer product of 2009, produced on the worldwide scale by the trillions. Approximately 1 million bags are used every minute.
·In the United States alone, an estimated 12 million barrels of oil is used annually to make plastic bags that Americans consume, which works out to over 100 billion (bags) per year.
·Impact of manufacturing 9 plastic bags is greater than that of driving a car 6/10 of a mile. This means that the annual consumption of plastic bags in the US (100 billion) is the equivalent of driving a car 6.67 billion miles… or more than 35 round trips from the Earth to the Sun.
·Each ton of recycled bags saves the energy equivalent of 11 barrels of oil.
·EPA estimates only 12% of plastic bags are being recycled.
·In 2011 alone we placed 200 million plastic bags into landfills.
·Once plastic has photodegraded to minute pieces in our oceans (often called a plastic soup), these small pieces of plastic are often mistaken by fish, birds or marine mammals and reptiles as food. Plastic particles provide no nutrients. As animals continue to feed on plastic, they take in more and more plastic material until they slowly starve to death.
·Plastic is found floating in all the world’s oceans, everywhere from polar region to the equator.
·Some parts of the ocean are like a plastic soup, where there are six pounds of plastic for every pound of plankton. Approx. 60-80% of marine debris is composed of plastics Approx. 80% of marine debris is from land-based sources.
·Over 100,000 marine mammals die each year from ingestion or entanglement in plastics and over 1 million sea birds.
·60-80% of marine debris is composed of plastics.

How can you help?  Our goal is to get as many of these bags made as possible, so every little bit will help. If you can't financially contribute, please share this campaign with all of your friends and family and through social media channels. Please remember to VOTE in the next election cycle.
We will be selling the Doug DoucheBAGS to simply cover our costs. 100% of proceeds raised after our costs are met will be donated to the Sierra Club Grand Canyon Chapter to help assist them with the great work they're doing.   Happy Earth Day!

story:
The Marathon of Light


We plan to drive an electric motorcycle around the world!

 Something never attempted before!
             Our goal is to demonstrate the practicality of green technology.
                                  WE KNOW THE WORLD IS IN TROUBLE! 
                                  WE ARE DOING SOMETHING ABOUT IT!
                                                     PLEASE JOIN US!

The Marathon of Light is about people, the earth and our future. We want to prove that green technology can help clean up our polluted world and adapt our lifestyles to climate change. The purpose is to prove the practical benefits of technology that uses clean, natural and sustainable energy. Our goal is to develop a new power grid that uses these kinds of power for everything: cars, homes and businesses.

We will champion people, social groups and environmentally conscious businesses who invest in new sources of power to protect nature, create green jobs and improve the health of our planet. Tomorrow belongs to the sun!

Our biggest challenge is funding, logistics and maintaining the momentum of such a long journey. With your financial support, we could prove that oil and petroleum energies are yesterday's power. Sustainable energy is the future!

This will all be documented on the Marathon of Light's Youtube channel. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The Marathon of Light will include:

America:

We will start at the Hearthstone Historic House Museum, in Appleton, Wisconsin, Built by businessman Henry James Rogers, the Hearthstone house was the first home in the world powered by the Edison system. From there, we will drive to eco-projects across the United States and tell the world about their progress.

Europe: 

We will travel from the West to the East of Europe, following the Danube River to the Black Sea harbor in Romania. We will explore European environmental projects and showcase their green-tech solutions. 

United Kingdom: 

We will begin at Cragside House, in Northumberland, U.K. It was built by Lord Armstrong in 1863 and was the first home in the world to be lit with hydroelectricity. From there, we will explore the British Isles and see what they've done to make our world green.

Japan: 

From the city of Kagoshima on the southern island of Kyushu to the city of Sapporo on the northern island of Hokkaido, the Marathon of Light will travel the length and breadth of this ancient civilization highlighting their environmental achievements.

All along the way, we will document projects capitalizing on solar, wind, ocean and earth power as well as environmentally friendly plans, business products and green energy services. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Our biggest challenge is funding, logistics and maintaining the momentum of such a long journey. Accordingly, the Marathon of Light will be a series of individual trips, each with the same purpose.

  • A target of $40,000 will help kick-start the Marathon of Light project.
  • Funds are for transportation costs, hotel and food expenses. We hope to avoid traveling by airplane to keep costs and pollution down. Ground travel will be the primary method. 
  • Youtube videos will update the Marathon of Light's progress for our followers as well as to document the people, places and businesses we visit. 
  • Your help is needed! Please join us in educating ourselves and the public about the environmental and financial benefits of green products. 
  • Contributors will be asked to help build an online "Green Book": a free database of people and businesses offering green products and services. 
  • A book and DVD of the journey will be published.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The Marathon of Light will symbolize the world's transformation from oil and gas based systems into one powered by renewable energy sources including solar, wind, ocean and earth (geothermal). 

We cannot succeed without your support. We are asking for your financial contribution to help bring this green world to life. We are all on a journey from a world of oil and petroleum to one powered by nature: a Marathon of Light!

We want to help build a sustainable reality!

We must act today to make a green tomorrow!



Let us work together and make the possible real!

story:
Help us Save The Saba Ecolodge!

Why should you help us Save The Saba Ecolodge? Are you passionate about the environment and want to share this passion with others, for generations to come? Do you have children, and want to share this beautiful earth we have with them? How can Saba's Ecolodge make a difference? Well, let us show you.

Saba, a tiny Caribbean island just 28 miles south of St. Maarten, offers a unique experience to any and all travelers.  Saba, known as The Unspoiled Queen, is proud of its nature and preservation efforts.  

In 2002, the construction of the Ecolodge was complete, and for over a decade it was successfully run by our friend Bernt. Tourists and locals alike enjoyed the off-grid living and serene beauty that the Ecolodge has to offer. Recently, Bernt passed away, and The Ecolodge has been in decline. In the last conversation I had with Bernt, he said “I wish someone would take over the Ecolodge and realize its full potential.”

We vow to turn The Saba Ecolodge into a holistic, off-grid retreat, where locals, tourists and volunteers can share their knowledge and experience. Our view for The Ecolodge allows us to offer classes in yoga, meditation, cooking, foraging adventures, gardening, host youth environmental programs and youth retreat programs, and much more.

"We", Keith and Kelly, have been good friends for over 14 years. We have always had common interests and together share a vision for The Saba Ecolodge. Given our wide range of experience and skills, we really are the perfect fit for the Saba Ecolodge. 

A few months ago, The Saba Ecolodge was a disaster. It was heartbreaking to see the cabins so run down. The jungle had taken over and the restaurant was non-functional. We're working day-in and day-out, and are having much success. We're repairing cabins, landscaping, gardening, composting, building stone walls and steps. The restaurant is open and we're composing dishes, developing cocktails, having yoga classes, bonfires, barbeques, jam sessions, and have hosted 2 parties of more than 100 people. Most importantly, we're making some great friends along the way. And that’s just the tip of the iceberg for us.

We’ve got a lot of work ahead and many challenges to overcome. But, right now, the only thing in our way is the possibility of foreclosure. The bank hasn't been paid in quite some time, and they’re ready to drop the gauntlet. We've submitted a business plan, and have been given 1 month to make it happen. That’s why we’re asking for $150,000, to keep the Ecolodge from going into foreclosure.               

The island of Saba needs The Ecolodge, and The Ecolodge needs you. So please make a contribution, like us on Facebook, and help us get this message out. Together we can Save The Saba Ecolodge!

story:
THE PROBLEM.

Since the Keurig craze began, over 60 billion K-Cups have ended up in landfills. In 2013, Keurig produced 8.3 billion more - enough to circle the world ten and a half times. These K-Cups aren't recyclable in most areas, so they get thrown away - ending up in landfills or floating in our oceans. Until a recyclable option becomes available, we need to find away to brew our coffee responsibly.

STARTING SMALL.

We can start by making a change on our campus. In many dorms, the only type of coffee machines allowed are single-serve. The only other way for students to get our coffee is to use a full meal swipe or pay $4.00 at Starbucks. Single-serve machines like the Keurig are the most affordable and easy way to make coffee, tea, or hot chocolate. At UNC there are currently around 18,000 undergrads. If 1 in 5 of those students has a Keurig and uses it just once a day, that's 809, 400 K-Cups that we're putting into landfills each year. If 2 in 5 has a Keurig and uses it once a day, that's over 1.6 million. 


HOW WE CAN HELP.

The mission of this organization and website is to find a way to continue to use our Keurigs without such taking such a heavy toll on the environment. We want to start by collecting and recycling K-cups used on dorms in campus and sending them back to Keurig to use as fuel for it's facilities. Keurig sponsors a program called Grounds to Grow On that offers collection boxes and pick-up service for discarded K-Cups. Unfortunately, these collection boxes cost $100 each. Our goal is to install a collection box on every floor of the freshman residence halls on campus by the end of the Fall 2015 semester, and we need your help!

story:
Thank you everyone that came out last night! 
We had just over 25 people come through the studio last night and ran the demo twice for the different crowds. Raised an addition $560! so thank you to those that contributed to the campaign. These funds will go directly to paying for the LEDs.
There's still time left for those that want to get in on the campaign. Check the perks and make your selection, this is one of the few times they will be available.
If you want to come by the studio for a demo, just contact me to make the arrangements. Thanks, Christopher & Tim.

The final event is this Saturday 11th at the studio!

We will have on display for the event just over 3000 LED's with some artwork samples build in. Hope you can make it - anytime after 7:30 or call me if you want to come at a different time. 905-730-4008. 

Only 7 days left! While we realize we will not meet the goal, we are very happy that a good portion of the LED purchase will be covered by everyone supporting the project, so thank you all. Tim has completed the hand wired power supplies (x4) that are required for the display Saturday. Check the gallery for images. The LED's are mounted on salvaged and refinished 2x8's that stretch out just over 16' along the studio wall. We may not need house lights for this event! I'm really looking forward to some community feedback on the set up and the artwork, so come on by or email/call to set up another time. Contribute to the campaign before it ends and be a part of The Campaign for Awesome - It's feels really good!

So what is The Machine of Awesome Bright Liquid Blueness?

Over 10,000 LEDs bright is what it is. It's an interactive sculpture, but more than that, it's a tool for connectedness. It offers the opportunity for individual as well as communal engagement, and dialogue on awesome bright liquid blueness.

The Machine of Awesome Bright Liquid Blueness wants you to solve it, and you will be rewarded for seeing what needs to be done. It wants you to touch it in special places, to embrace it. But what it needs right now is your support. Join the campaign to build The Machine of Awesome, and be eternally showered in bright liquid blueness.

Now, give me the details.

The Machine of Awesome (for short) will be mounted on the wall and measures 96cm tall by 80cm wide and 30cm deep. The front, sides, top, and bottom, are completely covered with tight strips of LED lights. Also on the front, running along the right side is a ‘control panel’. Now, as you can imagine, the front of the piece, with its tight strips of LED lights creates what could be called a super low-resolution pixelated screen. (or at least that is what I’m calling it)  The screen, when not activated by the audience, will be swirling and pulsing to its own personal beat. But upon approach, the audience will become a part of that beat. (you won't be able to help yourself)

Flashing randomly, and being difficult to read depending on proximity, will be simple but exciting messages. “The Most Amazing!” “Revitalizing!” “Refresh & Survive!” “Live!” – (hopefully you get the idea here.) Also “$2 Play!” “Winner EveryTime!”

Upon closer viewing the ‘control panel’ will feature instructions. Those instructions, printed like you would have seen on an old pinball machine, will read as such:

INSTRUCTIONS

1)  Insert Toonie.

2)  Touch me in the right places.

3)  Winner EveryTime!

Pretty straightforward right?


So what happens when you insert a Toonie?

First off, the machine goes wild with bright crazy excitement saying Thank You! Once it composes itself, mounted near the top of the control panel is an hour glass with five minutes worth of sand in it, and it rotates. BEGIN!

The LED’s flash and a new super low-resolution pixelated image covers the front with what looks to be an old Space Invaders game. The shapes are a little different, but they are moving toward you and you better do something about it. You touch the ship on the bottom of the screen and it shoots a yellow laser beam. Miss! They are getting closer, moving faster. You fire again, this time….

Suddenly a fish swims up from the bottom of the screen. Moving through the water, it settles down near the bottom of the screen. Fighting against the current, the fish encounters debris floating down the stream. The fish needs your help - dodging and weaving you do your best to keep the fish safe.

The screen flashes and dissolves into an image of a beautiful tree. There it is, in all its glory. Leaves gently swaying in the wind. But what’s next? What do you do with this tree? Text begins to flash up around the tree, but you are standing to close to read the super low-resolution pixelated words. Turning you look to those around you for help. What does it say? It says….

The Machine of Awesome Bright Liquid Blueness explodes with colour! “WINNER!” flashing on the screen. Pulsing and dancing you can hear the hum of small electronic motors. A prize drops from the control panel. Pulling the prize from the holder, you see  further instructions. Now it’s your turn.

The Team.

Only through community will The Machine of Awesome Bright Liquid Blueness get built, shared, and enjoyed.

Christopher McLeod: Visual Artist, instigator, collaborator, and critic. For a closer look go to - www.christophermcleod.ca

'Tim the Tech' Tim: Programmer & Master of electronics with training in robotics. A tinkerer and solver. 


Hali Tsui: Editor and advisor. A guide sharing wisdom and insight.

Chris Krucker: Freerange organic farmer & visionary. (no growth hormones in him) A knower and rabble rouser. www.manorun.ca


FINAL EVENT - April 11th at the studio.

We will be hosting our final fundraising event at the studio April 11th so drop in anytime after 7:30pm. Please email mail@christophermcleod.ca to confirm the address. BYOB.

We will be demonstrating different interactive aspects from the prototype for you to try and have fun with. Come on by and we look forward to seeing you.


You’re Invited – Friday March 13th.  - (The event was great and thanks to everyone that came out. The campaign received several cash donations that evening which has already been applied to the cost of the LED's.)

ManoRun is hosting The Machine of Awesome Bright Liquid Blueness kick off party Friday March 13th. Come and experience ManoRun's exploration of indigenous plants and diet. The evening will be a taste experience of local grown heirloom corn, home made mole's and tortillas. For the last 3 years the farm has been developing it's ability to grow food that would have been grown here before European's arrived and also incorporating that food into our diet. Denise, Chris and Kaleb recently visited Oaxaca, Mexico which is known as the agricultural cradle of the America's having had a profound impact on plant diversity within these hemispheres. For those that can come early  - you can help make tortillas, and for those that come later you can enjoy these wonders of the gastronomic world.

4:30 pm tortillas making

6:30 pm tortillas and mole eating

The entire team will be on hand and we look forward to meeting everyone. 


So where are we at, and where are we going?

A big part of this campaign will be keeping campaign members up to date on the progress of the piece. We are interested in your feedback and look forward to hearing from people with questions. I will be posting photos and videos as the progress is made.

Currently in the studio: a scale model of The Machine of Awesome that we are using to test mechanisms. The coin mechanism has also been drawn up and I will begin fabricating that immediately. We have begun testing the programming and Tim has started on a computer simulation program that will allow me to start inputing artwork and learning how to control over 10,000 individual LEDs.

I have purchased and all the LED's have now arrived.

And where are we going? The prototype is going to be first exhibited at Emily Carr University in July this summer. You are all invited of course. From there…..

The screen flashes and dissolves into
an image of a beautiful tree. There it is, in all its glory. Leaves gently
swaying in the wind. But what’s next? What do you do with this tree? Text
begins to flash up around the tree, but you are standing to close to read the
super low-resolution pixelated words. Turning you look to those around you for
help. What does it say? It says….
The Machine of Awesome Bright Liquid
Blueness explodes with colour! “WINNER!” flashing on the screen. Pulsing and
dancing you can hear the hum of small electronic motors. A prize drops from the
control panel. Pulling the prize from the holder, you see  further instructions. Now it’s your turn.
The Team.
Only through community will The
Machine of Awesome Bright Liquid Blueness get built, shared, and enjoyed.
Christopher McLeod: Visual Artist,
instigator, collaborator, and critic. For a closer look go to - www.christophermcleod.ca
'Tim the Tech' Tim: Programmer &
Master of electronics with training in robotics. A tinkerer and solver. 
Hali Tsui: Editor and advisor. A guide sharing wisdom and insight.Chris Krucker: Freerange organic
farmer & visionary. (no growth hormones in him) A knower and rabble rouser.
www.manorun.ca
FINAL EVENT - April 11th at the studio.We will be hosting our final fundraising event at the studio April 11th so drop in anytime after 7:30pm. Please email mail@christophermcleod.ca to confirm the address. BYOB.We will be demonstrating different interactive aspects from the prototype for you to try and have fun with. Come on by and we look forward to seeing you.You’re Invited – Friday March 13th.  - (The event was great and thanks to everyone that came out. The campaign received several cash donations that evening which has already been applied to the cost of the LED's.)

ManoRun is hosting The Machine of
Awesome Bright Liquid Blueness kick off party Friday March 13th. Come and
experience ManoRun's exploration of indigenous plants and diet. The evening
will be a taste experience of local grown heirloom corn, home made mole's and
tortillas. For the last 3 years the farm has been developing it's ability to
grow food that would have been grown here before European's arrived and also
incorporating that food into our diet. Denise, Chris and Kaleb recently visited
Oaxaca, Mexico which is known as the agricultural cradle of the America's
having had a profound impact on plant diversity within these hemispheres. For
those that can come early  - you can help make tortillas, and for
those that come later you can enjoy these wonders of the gastronomic world.
4:30 pm tortillas making
6:30 pm tortillas and mole eating
The entire team will be on hand and we look forward to meeting
everyone. 

So where are we at, and where are we
going?
A big part of this campaign will be
keeping campaign members up to date on the progress of the piece. We are
interested in your feedback and look forward to hearing from people with
questions. I will be posting photos and videos as the progress is made.
Currently in the studio: a scale
model of The Machine of Awesome that we are using to test mechanisms. The coin mechanism has also been drawn up and I will
begin fabricating that immediately. We have begun testing the programming and
Tim has started on a computer simulation program that will allow me to start
inputing artwork and learning how to control over 10,000 individual LEDs.
I have purchased and all the LED's have now arrived.
And where are we going? The prototype is going to be first
exhibited at Emily Carr University in July this summer. You are all invited of course.
From there…..

story:
When we first thought about Biotutacide, we asked Gazan farmers about the most problematic issues they face in their farms, and of course there were many..!

It was the tomato pest  “Tuta absoluta”  one of the biggest problems that destroys their  crops and harmed  the agricultural sector in Gaza during the last three years.

It was then that  we decided to work on a biological pesticide that would control this  pathogenic pest in their farms effectively, doesn’t affect the health & environment, sustains the crops and the food needs of other people .... Thus, we worked on “Biotutacide”.


What’s new with Biotutacide ?

Biotutacideis a biological alternative to chemical pesticides that employs
“Beauveria bassiana” fungus to control tomato pest "Tuta absoluta" and eliminate it.It is the result of over two years of research and development, and feedback from many farmers.

Our aim ? 
To develop  Biotutacide as one of the best solutions to control the plant pathogenic pest   “Tuta absoluta”  in order to reduce the risks raised from the excessive use and misuse of agrochemicals.


The result ? Beauveria bassiana- based bio-fungicide as a ready to use formulations,are developed and marketed  for the first time in our region to control the destructive tomato pest.

These formulations are  effective, reliable, support the availability of high quality food, reduce the exposure to chemical pesticide and improve crop production  in our region.


Why Beginning with the tomato pest ?
The tomato pest “ Tuta absoluta “ is a very harmful pest of tomatoes  and other vegetable crops including eggplants, peppers and potatoes.
Tuta absoluta can cause 50-100% yield reduction on tomato crops. Thus, we’ve  chosen to begin with this pest as it caused heavy lossesto farmers in Gaza strip.

How does Biotutacide work? 


Essential needs of Biotutacide 

According to Palestinian statistics 2014, the total area of cultivated land in
Gaza Strip  is about 150,000 acres of  which 75,000 vegetable farms.

Farmers need pesticides periodically in order to maintain their crops production and control the agricultural pests, but  farmers use these chemicals excessively, which cause a negative impact on both the environment and our health.

Gaza strip  suffers from a high rate of cancer diseases, and it was reported that chemical pesticides is one of the main causes.!! Take in consideration that the number of cancer patients  in Gaza strip is about 12,600 patients, and the annual average of new cases is 59 case..
So, it seems that we have to make an action to save our health and control this average .!!

Therefore, the use of  the bio-pesticide is one of the best solutions to protect  the environment, control the spread of  plant diseases and moreover, it can provide healthy and clean food that allow us to be in this world.!

Our strategy

We first began as a research project, the results were promising and so we decided to develop a business plan as a primary step to establish a startup company for biological pesticides products.



We worked on the original results for almost a year then we’ve had two additional years of production experience, our team has also grown, and now we’re doing things better than ever.

Now, we’re ready to begin full production of 50 liters of Biotutacide as soon as we successfully raise the requested amount of this campaign.

Beginning with  Biotutacide and with environmentally-friendly supporters, we’re  continuing to develop more biological products to control other  pests that would be available anytime for local and global markets.!


How your contributions will be used?

1400 $ =  Production of 50 L of Biotutacide

800 $ >> “ Production materials , Growth media and disposables “.

400 $ >> Finishing and Packaging the product.

200 $ >> Marketing of the product.

Who are we?

We are a team of entrepreneurial  researchers supervised by a professor of  plant  science and mycology “Prof. Abboud El. Kichaoui - Supervisor of Biological Control Unit – IUG”.  In addition to administration and business development team members.

Thanks  in Advance

Thanks so much for taking the time to read through our campaign to produce the first biological pesticide in Gaza.
We trust you can see that we are passionate about this critical project and that it is of  real significance to all of us. We are looking for equally passionate supporters who can join with us on this project.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't afford to donate yourself don't forget to share the link of the campaign with family, friends and anyone else with an interest through Facebook, Twitter and other social media to spread the word.

This project is important as it will develop the only biological pesticide against tomato pest in Gaza strip.

Last but not least .. Many Thanks to everyone who support  us during the production of Biotutacide  prototype especially “ Laboratories of Biotechnology Department at the Islamic university of Gaza ( IUG) and a lot thanks to PalCinema for their great efforts.

Contact us
If you have any question or comment you can contact us at: biotutacideproject@gmail.com

story:
The WCA mission is to protect children from pesticide drift and the environmental impacts of vineyard development next to our schools.

When the parents of 700 children discovered that a large-scale vineyard was planned for a site just feet away from the five schools our children attend in Sonoma County, CA, we decided to take a stand to protect the children from exposure to pesticides that could drift onto the playgrounds, and we joined to form the Watertrough Children’s Alliance (WCA).

Reaching out to the vineyard developer was the first step in protecting our children, but the developer was not willing to yield to parental requests. He would not consider going organic, using fewer pesticides, or changing his approach to vineyard management even when faced with evidence that pesticide use near schools is extremely dangerous to children. (See Pesticide Action Network for more info: http://www.panna.org/children).

When the good neighbor approach failed, WCA took action politically with the County Supervisors and the Agricultural Commissioner, but after in-depth research about county processes, we discovered we were facing a real problem with the lack of environmental protection connected with vineyards, not just in our area but all over the state. It was time to take steps to make a change in the status quo and bring real environmental review to vineyard applications in Sonoma County.

Do we want RoundUp, a known carcinogen, along with sulphur and other pesticides sprayed near our kids? The answer is a resounding NO!

We are now at a place in our mission where we need to hire pesticide scientists and legal experts, so WCA has asked the OWL Foundation, an environmental watch group, to be our fiscal sponsor.  OWL Foundation has a long history of protecting Openspace, Water and Land in Sonoma County and they have agreed to take us under their wing, so to speak! WCA began fundraising with bake sales and garage sales – but we are still $5,000 short of our goal.  We need only $5,000 to be able to take a big step toward actual environmental review for this type of project – and we can’t emphasize enough how important this is for the environment, not only in our county, but all over California. Our case could set a precedent that would start a landslide toward upholding real environmental standards for all pesticide-related development projects in the entire state.

If WCA is able to achieve our goal, the tables will be turned on vineyards that use pesticides near schools - which currently get the green light with absolutely no environmental review.  This will be a pivotal moment in environmental action – come be a part of it!

Help us protect our children and your children from pesticides at school – donate today!

Even if you can’t donate today, you can help forward the WCA mission by sharing our campaign. Get the word out on Facebook. Make some noise on the interwebs! Use the Indiegogo share tools! Parents and communities united are unstoppable, and we love your support!

story:
The Need Continues After Nepal is out of the Headlines

Few global catastrophes have been met with such resilience and compassion for others than the Nepal Earthquake. The Nepalese people are doing everything they can to care for their families and neighbors in this life-changing event. Many families in and around Katmandu tonight are living in make-shift encampments. 

Many great aid organizations from all over the world are providing vital food, clean water and medical assistance, but a critical element that is much needed is missing; sanitation. With broken sewers and waste management infrastructure, waste out in the open can be carried into water supplies through rainwater runoff. 


A biogas digester is a special tank that converts organic matter like food scraps, toilet waste and animal manure. Biogas digesters solve two critical problems at this important time:

  • Safely dispose of organic waste.
  • Create energy for cooking, pasteurizing water, sanitizing medical equipment and fueling generators for electricity.

Nepal had the largest number of biogas digesters per capita of any country in the world. Unfortunately, most of these were made with unreinforced masonry and were damaged during the earthquake. It only takes a small crack to render a biogas digester unusable.

American biogas manufacturer Hestia Home Biogas is partnering with Flexi Biogas in Nairobi, Kenya to provide much-needed biogas digesters to Nepal. 

We are asking contributors to help fund shipments of 2 cubic meter Hestia units, which are insulated against the cold Nepal climate. And 4, 6 and 10 cubic meter bag-type digesters from Flexigas.  

Starting May 1, 2015, any purchase of a home biogas digester from Hestia at the regular price of $3,995, Hestia will donate a second unit to Nepal. 

$1,500 and $1,000 contributions will go towards a Flexi-biogas system shipped from Nairobi, Kenya. 

All contributions of entire systems will receive the best perk ever. A personalized video thank-you message from our friends in Katmandu, Nepal.
